Review Paper Research status and outlook of molecular sieve NH3-SCR catalysts Yuheng Yuan Bin Guan Conceptualization Supervision Validation Writing – original draft ⁎ Junyan Chen Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Zhongqi Zhuang Writing – original draft Chunzheng Zheng Writing – original draft Jiefei Zhou Writing – original draft Tianxu Su Writing – original draft Chenyu Zhu Writing – original draft Jiangfeng Guo Writing – original draft Hongtao Dang Writing – original draft Yaoyao Zhang Writing – review & editing Xuehan Hu Writing – original draft Sikai Zhao Writing – original draft Chao Yi Writing – original draft Chengze Xu Writing – original draft Bingyu Xu Writing – original draft Wenbo Zeng Writing – original draft Yang He Writing – original draft Zhihao Wei Writing – original draft Zhen Huang Supervision Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering of Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Dongchuan Road No.800, Min Hang District, Shanghai 200240, PR China Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering of Ministry of Education Shanghai Jiao Tong University Dongchuan Road No.800, Min Hang District Shanghai 200240 PR China Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering of Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Dongchuan Road No.800, Min Hang District, Shanghai 200240, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. NH3-SCR technology is a highly efficient denitrification technology that is widely used in the purification of diesel exhaust and coal-fired flue gas from thermal power plants. Molecular sieve catalysts have been extensively investigated for their high activity and selectivity. In this review, the preparation, structure, active sites and some resistances of Cu-based molecular sieve catalysts, Fe-based molecular sieve catalysts and composite metal molecular sieve catalysts are systematically investigated for relevant elaboration. In addition, the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over the catalysts is also explained. With the increasingly stringent requirements of NO x emission, we need to develop more efficient catalysts. This paper provides a summary of the hydrothermal aging stability and the inorganic element (S / P / Alkali and alkaline earth metal) poisoning mechanisms as well as the influence of the preparation process in the molecular sieve catalysts, and we hope this review contributes to the development of molecular sieve catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR Cu-based zeolite Fe-based zeolite Bimetallic-based zeolite Resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction NO x (mainly NO and NO2) is very harmful to the environment, causing acid rain, photochemical smog, and so on. They are mainly produced during the combustion of fossil fuels from stationary sources, such as coal-fired power plants and mobile sources such as motor vehicles. At present, with the large amount of fossil fuels being used, the production of NO x has become more and more significant, and how to reduce NO x emissions is something we need to pay close attention to. Although modifications to combustion systems have been widely used to reduce NO x emissions, post-combustion flue gas treatment technologies are still needed to meet increasingly stringent emission standards. In particular, different catalytic reduction technologies have been used to reduce NO x from stationary and or mobile sources. Among them, the NH3 selective catalytic reduction of NO x technology (NH3-SCR: 4NO + 4NH3 + O2 → 4N2 + 6H2O) is currently the best developed and most widely used NO x emission control technology due to its high efficiency, good selectivity and low cost. NH3-SCR technology plays an important role in various industrial sectors, including automotive exhaust treatment, power generation, and chemical production, as a primary method for reducing NO x emissions. The catalyst plays a key role in the development of NH3-SCR technology. It utilizes NH3 to react with NO x on the surface or inside the catalyst for SCR to achieve the purpose of de-emission. However, increasingly stringent emission regulations place higher demands on NH3-SCR catalysts, including: (1) Wide operating window and high stability. Catalysts with a wide temperature window can be applied to a wide range of operating conditions. For example, LT-SCR (Low temperature-SCR) catalysts can be placed behind electro-precipitation and desulfurization units in power plants to minimize the toxic effects of SO2 and toxic metals in the dust. SCR units are typically installed behind diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC) and diesel particulate filter (DPF) units. The regeneration process of the DPF system raises the temperature of the exhaust gases, which requires the catalysts to have better high temperature activity and stability. (2) High resistance to SO2/H2O at low temperatures. Under actual operating conditions, the presence of H2O and SO2 in the exhaust gas leads to the deposition of (NH4)2SO4/NH4HSO4 and metal sulfates. Due to the high decomposition temperature of sulfate (> 300 °C), there is a need to develop low-temperature SO2/H2O resistant catalysts that can effectively inhibit sulfate generation or promote sulfate decomposition at low temperatures. (3) Excellent resistance to poisoning by P (phosphorus) and alkali and alkaline earth metals. Fuel impurities and related additives will be involved in the combustion process, making the exhaust gas contain phosphorus, alkali metals, alkaline earth metals and other elements, which will lead to SCR catalyst poisoning. It seriously affects the activity and selectivity of the catalyst, and also determines the speed and conversion rate of the SCR reaction. Currently, after decades of research and optimization, the hydrothermal stability of catalysts is no longer a pressing issue. However, impurities present in the exhaust system, such as sulfur and alkali metals, can severely impact the catalyst's performance. Improving resistance to these impurities is a critical challenge that needs to be addressed. An ideal SCR catalyst for commercialization should have low cost, excellent performance, and good stability. Early SCR catalysts were based on noble metals, but they were expensive, had a narrow temperature range, were prone to poisoning, and not suitable for large-scale industrial production. In the 1980s, vanadium-titanium-based SCR catalysts emerged and gradually achieved commercialization. They exhibited high NO x reduction efficiency but had a narrow temperature range, were susceptible to sulfur poisoning, and had adverse environmental impacts. To better meet the requirements of industrial applications, a new class of SCR catalysts was developed – molecular sieve catalysts. At present, molecular sieve catalyst has gradually become a research hot spot in recent years because of its high activity and selectivity. The initial focus of research was on copper-based zeolites. In the 1990s, Held et al. [1] first proposed the SCR reaction on copper zeolites using urea as a reducing agent, and Iwamoto et al. [2] discovered the high catalytic activity of Cu-exchanged zeolites. However, it was not until 2010 that SSZ-13 zeolite, known for its excellent hydrothermal stability, achieved commercialization and was successfully applied in diesel vehicles [3]. The structure of a catalyst influences the coordination of active elements, which in turn affects the catalytic activity. In molecular sieve catalysts, the molecular sieve acts as a carrier for the active species and plays a crucial role. The basic structure of a molecular sieve framework consists of SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedra linked together by shared oxygen atoms, forming a three-dimensional crystalline network. Since the AlO4 tetrahedron carries a negative charge, it can combine with cations to achieve charge neutrality. For example, in copper-based molecular sieve catalysts, Cu2+ can form Lewis acid sites or copper dimers by combining with the AlO4 tetrahedra. When combined with H+, Brønsted acid sites are formed. These acid sites are responsible for the adsorption and activation of NH3 on the molecular sieve catalyst. The molecular sieve framework also contains characteristic cage-like structural units. Based on the structure of these characteristic cages, molecular sieves can be classified into various types, such as CHA (such as SSZ-13, SAPO-34), AEI (such as SSZ-16), MFI (such as ZSM-5), and AFX (such as SSZ-39). The specific cage structure will be further discussed in the following text. In accordance with the aforementioned description, Molecular sieve catalysts can be categorized according to the type of active sites into monometallic molecular sieve catalysts including Cu-based molecular sieve catalysts, Fe-based molecular sieve catalysts, etc., composite metal molecular sieve catalysts including (Cu-Mn composite metal, Cu-Fe composite metal, Cu-Ce composite metal, etc.), and according to the size of the pores can be categorized into small pore molecular sieves, mesoporous molecular sieves and macroporous molecular sieves. There are various methods for preparing molecular sieve catalysts, including ion exchange, in-situ hydrothermal synthesis, impregnation, sol-gel, solvent-thermal synthesis, and vapor deposition. Ion exchange can be further classified into solid-state ion exchange and liquid-phase ion exchange. Liquid-phase ion exchange is the conventional preparation method, in which the molecular sieve samples are added to the corresponding salt solution (such as Cu(NO3)2), and the related molecular sieve catalysts can be produced after continuous stirring, washing, drying, and roasting and activation. The solid-phase ion exchange method is to mix the copper salt or its oxides with the molecular sieve carriers, mix them evenly through mechanical ball milling and other methods, and then produce molecular sieve catalysts after high temperature roasting. Compared with the liquid-phase ion-exchange method, the molecular sieve prepared by this method has better hydrothermal stability and saves several steps such as washing and drying, which is easy to operate and avoids the generation of waste aqueous solution containing metal ions, but the long time high-temperature roasting can easily damage the molecular sieve pores, which in turn seriously affects its denitrification activity. The in-situ hydrothermal synthesis method, also known as the one-pot method, involves the introduction of the active element while synthesizing the molecular sieve skeleton to directly prepare the finished product. Microwave radiation synthesis is a hydrothermal synthesis method using microwave as thermal energy instead of high temperature heating, which has the advantages of fast reaction speed, mild reaction conditions, low energy consumption, narrow particle size distribution of molecular sieves, high purity and homogeneous morphology. In-situ hydrothermal synthesis method and microwave irradiation synthesis method are hydrothermal synthesis method, the difference between the two is that the former uses high temperature water heat as thermal energy, the latter is the use of microwave as thermal energy. Impregnation method involves immersing the molecular sieve support in a solution containing metal precursors, followed by drying and calcination steps to convert the metal precursors into active metal particles, thereby preparing the molecular sieve catalyst. This method allows for control over the size and distribution of the metal particles and is relatively simple and feasible. Sol-gel method involves crosslinking the components of a sol in a gel state to form a uniform molecular sieve structure, which is then calcined to obtain the catalyst. This method enables the formation of highly dispersed metal active sites and allows control over the pore structure and surface properties of the catalyst. Gas-phase deposition method involves introducing gaseous precursors into a reactor, where they deposit and form the catalyst on the surface of the support. This method achieves high dispersion and uniformity of the catalyst and offers control over the metal loading and distribution. It should be noted that the synthesis of molecular sieves in these methods typically requires the use of template agents. Template agents play a role in guiding the formation of specific structures during the molecular sieve synthesis process. Common template agents include organic amines, organic cations, and surfactants. The choice of an appropriate template agent can affect the topological structure, pore structure, and acid-base properties of the molecular sieve, thereby influencing the performance of the catalyst. In summary, the different preparation methods and the selection of template agents can impact the SCR performance of the catalyst. In each section concerning the specific preparation method, the introduction of relevant molecular sieve template agents and the effects of different synthesis methods on catalyst performance will be discussed. This review selects some molecular sieve catalysts with more excellent performance such as Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SAPO-34, etc., and elaborates related to their preparation, structure, active position, reaction mechanism and some resistances. It is hoped that it can help the researchers to provide a little help to the existing research. 2 Cu-based molecular sieve catalysts Cu-based molecular sieve catalysts are the most widely studied molecular sieve catalysts, Table 1 summarizes the active Cu position, hydrothermal stability, P poisoning and alkali metal/alkaline earth metal effects on Cu-based zeolite catalysts with different carriers as shown in the table. 2.1 Cu-SSZ-13 2.1.1 Preparation Kawk et al. [4] synthesized H-SSZ-13 with a skeleton Si/Al of 4.2 by using N,N,N-trimethyl-1-adamantylammonium hydroxide(TMAda-OH) as a templating agent. However, the use of this method to synthesize the of molecular sieve carriers requires expensive templating agents and is not suitable for industrial production and application. Subsequently, Xu et al. [5] demonstrated by density functional theory (DFT) and PED calculations that choline chloride dimer has a spatial structure matching the CHA cage and possesses (CHX)4N+ and C-OH, two functional groups that are essential for the construction of the backbone structure. Therefore, choline chloride can replace TMAda-OH as a templating agent to synthesize SSZ-13 molecular sieves. In addition, choline chloride has the advantages of cheap, non-toxic and environmentally friendly, which reduces the synthesis cost of molecular sieves and gets rid of the dependence on expensive template agents. Han et al. [6] reported that compared with the traditional chemical synthesis method, the synthesis of SSZ-13 molecular sieves using coal gangue synthesis method can be shortened by 7 h, which reduces the time cost. Coal gangue is a solid waste produced in coal mine production, through which the synthesis of SSZ-13 helps resource recycling and environmental protection. Using the synthesized SSZ-13 molecular sieves, they synthesized Cu-SSZ-13 by ion-exchange method, which was found to have a wide temperature window (180 ∼ 400 °C) and high catalytic activity. The performance of catalysts obtained by different preparation methods varies. Zhang et al. [7] prepared Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts with similar Si/Al and Cu/Al ratios by liquid-phase ion-exchange method (Cu-SSZ-13-I) and one-pot synthesis method (Cu-SSZ-13-O), and investigated and compared their catalytic activities and physicochemical properties. Cu-SSZ-13-O showed higher low-temperature denitrification activity than Cu-SSZ-13-I by the presence of more Cu2+ ions. In addition, Cu-SSZ-13-O is less affected by pore (i.e., intracrystalline) diffusion limitations at low reaction temperatures. Different Cu/Al ratios, i.e., different Cu loadings, affect the content of Cu species within the catalyst, which in turn affects the activity of the catalyst. Chen et al. [8] prepared Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts with different Cu contents by a one-pot method, and concluded that the active Cu2+ content within the catalyst increases as the Cu content is increased, and the low-temperature activity of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst gradually. Guan et al. [9] concluded that high Cu is detrimental to the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13. They found that the higher the Cu/Al ratio, the easier it is to deactivate Cu-SSZ-13 during hydrothermal aging. The Si/Al ratio has an important effect on the structure and performance of catalysts, and the higher the Si/Al ratio, the better the hydrothermal stability of the catalysts [9–11]. The silica-to-alumina ratio can influence the content of copper coordination species in the catalyst, thereby affecting the catalyst's performance. According to the studies conducted by Kwak et al. [12] and Paolucci et al. [13], Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts exhibit two active sites, namely Z2Cu and ZCuOH. Further elaboration on these sites will be provided in Section 2.1.2. However, for all Si/Al ratios of SSZ-13, Cu ions are first designated as Z2Cu until all paired frames are saturated with Al, and then continue to be designated as ZCuOH on isolated frames of Al [13]. This implies that the Z2Cu species are still present in the high Si/Al samples, but at much lower densities than in the low Si/Al samples. In catalysts with low Si/Al ratios, the Cu2+ ion is mainly located near the 6MR (6-membered ring) window and coordinated to two Al sites (Z2Cu). In contrast, for samples with high Si/Al or high Cu/Al ratios, the isolated Cu2+ is mainly located in the 8MR (8-membered ring) and is coordinated to only one Al site (ZCuOH) [9,14]. The decrease in specific surface area of Cu-SSZ-13 with high Si/Al ratio after hydrothermal aging is low [9]. However, an increase in the Si/Al ratio decreases the total Cu2+ species, especially the α-type Cu2+ species (Z2Cu), and reduces the Cu-SSZ-13 catalytic activity[10,11]. He et al. [15] reported the synthesis of crystalline Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts from different silicon sources, including colloidal silicon (silica sol), gel silicon (silica gel), and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS). Cu-SSZ-13 prepared from TEOS showed a clear advantage in catalytic activity in the low-temperature region (< 200 °C). However, Cu-SSZ-13 from silica gel exhibited excellent total catalytic activity (200 ∼ 600 °C) in all three samples. In addition, Cu-SSZ-13 from silica sol showed better hydrothermal stability after the same hydrothermal treatment, despite the similar pattern of movement of Cu2+ ions during the aging process. Therefore, the choice of silica sol as the precursor source is more favorable for the synthesis of Cu-SSZ-13. Post-synthesis treatment of zeolite materials has been widely used to tune the properties of carrier materials [16,17]. Oord et al. [16] and Sommer et al. [17] found that H-SSZ-13 zeolites with low Si/Al ratios could be obtained by treating H-SSZ-13 with desilication with sodium hydroxide solution. Wang et al. [18] found that alkali leaching could improve the low-temperature activity of the catalysts, but their water thermal stability deteriorated and the catalyst was more susceptible to dealumination leading to structural collapse. They found that the interaction of the active metal with the zeolite skeleton during alkali leaching induced the formation of Lewis acid sites, which improved the Cu-SSZ-13 redox capacity and effectively promoted the generation of Z2Cu. It also significantly accelerated the reaction rate of adsorbed NO x with NH3 by promoting the generation of NO2 and the activation of NH3. Cui et al. [19] found that Na+ and K+ inhibited the dealumination of the SSZ-13 zeolite frameworks during the hydrothermal aging process, which in turn improved the hydrothermal stability of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts with a low Si/Al ratio (Si/Al = 6). Lv et al. [11] found that the Cu-SSZ-13 samples loaded with alkali metal ions (Li+, Na+, K+ and Cs+) underwent only slight dealumination of the SSZ-13 zeolite skeleton after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment, and some ZCuOH species were transformed into Z2Cu species, which improved its low-temperature catalytic activity. The content of paired Al species, and distorted AlO4-tetrahedra and isolated Cu2+ species (especially Z2Cu) increased in Cu-SSZ-13 as the radius of the alkali metal cations decreased. Chen et al. [20] prepared sodium-containing Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts by residual (R), ion-exchange (IE), and impregnation (IP) methods to study the the effects of different methods of Na+ introduction on the hydrothermal aging of Cu-SSZ-13. The relevant mechanism of action is shown in Fig. 1 . Compared with R-Na-Cu-SSZ-13, more ZCuOH species were dispersed in the IE-Na-Cu-SSZ-13 cage, which resulted in unfavorable hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13. However, R-Na and IE-Na can protect the Al-O-Si bonds during hydrothermal aging. IP-Na will desilicate during the introduction of Na+ to form the H2Si2O5 and Al(OSi)1(OH)3 configurations, which leads to the degradation of the zeolite framework and a severe reduction in the activity of the catalyst. In summary, the introduction of Na via R-Na is the best and favors the stability of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. 2.1.2 Structure and active site As shown in Fig. 2 , Cu-SSZ-13 is a CHA-type catalyst with a rhombic zeolite structure consisting of double 6MR prisms stacked in the order of AABBCCAA. This allows for the formation of large CHA cavities where Cu species can enter through the three-dimensional 8MR pore system. After ion exchange of Cu ions, the CHA topology tends to form highly reactive Cu+ ions and Cu2+ ions rather than CuO x species, which facilitates the selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3 [12]. Much research has also been done on the Cu active sites on Cu-SSZ-13 and related properties. Kwak et al. [12] found that there are two types of Cu active sites in Cu-SSZ-13, one at the 6MR position and the other at the large cage near the 8MR. Lv et al. [11] suggested that Cu fallout located in the Z2Cu equilibrating paired Al sites in D6MRs (double 6-membered rings) is the main active site for the SCR of NO with NH3, ZCuOH (β-type Cu2+) compensating for the isolated Al sites in the CHA cages and catalytically less active, and γ-type Cu2+ adsorbed on the out-of-framework Al2O3 is almost inactive. Chen et al. [8] found that active Cu2+ located at different positions in the CHA cages in the NH3-SCR reaction with different properties. As shown in Fig. 3 , Cu1 is located near the 8MR window, and this species plays a crucial role in the low-temperature activity and has the best reduction energy; Cu2 is located in the supercage that deviates from the double hexagonal ring, with the highest content and better hydrothermal stability; Cu3 is located in the center of the hexagonal prism, this species is the most stable and the least active, and its content remains basically unchanged after SO2 pretreatment, which has better SO2 resistance. The three active Cu2+ have the highest content of Cu2. Z2Cu, ZCuOH, and Brønsted acid sites are present in Cu-SSZ-13, and the specific structure is shown in Fig. 4 . Both Z2Cu and ZCuOH are active sites for the SCR reaction, but the main active site for the oxidation reaction is only ZCuOH [21]. The stabilized Cu2+ ion is the key to excellent low-temperature denitrification activity. The Cu2+ ions not only provide Lewis acid sites, but also play a key role in NO x adsorption or activation. Moreover, in the NH3-SCR reaction, NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites is more active than on Brønsted acid sites [7]. The reactive species may also be different under different reaction conditions. Deka et al. [22] found by combining experimental and DFT calculations that only Cu2+ was present in the molecular sieves under fast SCR reaction conditions (NO:NO2 = 1:1), whereas the four-coordinated Cu2+ on the surface of the catalyst as well as the two-coordinated Cu+ bound to water were the most stable reactive components. Lomachenko et al. [23] found that both Z2Cu and ZCuOH were active in low-temperature (below 200 °C) SCR reactions, while in high-temperature (above 250 °C) SCR reactions where the catalyst activity increases dramatically, Z2Cu is the active substance. Gao et al. [24] concluded that for standard SCR reactions, when the reaction temperature was lower than 250 °C, the active component in the low Cu loading samples the active component is copper dimer. The copper dimer is less stable at 250 ∼ 350 °C, and the SCR reaction rate decreases accordingly. When the temperature is higher than 350 °C, the active component becomes Z2Cu that migrates to the surface of the 6MR. In the medium copper loading samples, Cu2+ in the form of ZCuOH that exists near the CHA cage and the eight-membered ring is also active in the low-temperature SCR reaction. 2.1.3 Hydrothermal aging properties Catalysts exposed to hot and humid environments for a long period of time will undergo aging and their activity will be affected, so the hydrothermal stability of the catalysts is the most important criterion for the application. Cu-SSZ-13 was commercialized in 2010 due to its excellent hydrothermal stability [3]. Kwak et al. [26] first totally reported that Cu-SSZ-13’s good hydrothermal stability. Fan et al. [27] found that the NH3-SCR performance of the fresh catalyst was well maintained after 12 h of hydrothermal aging treatment at 700 °C. When the aging temperature was increased to 750 °C, the catalytic activity of the catalyst decreased slightly in the low (<250 °C) and high (>475 °C) temperature ranges, which was attributed to the hydrothermal treatment leading to the loss of some active Cu species in the catalyst and the decrease of the surface acidity, whereas in the wider temperature ranges (250 ∼ 475 °C), the NO conversion could still be maintained at more than 90 %. Fig. 5 reveals the hydrothermal aging mechanism of Cu-SSZ-13. The effects of high-temperature hydrothermal aging on the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst can be attributed to the following: (i) molecular sieve de-alumina, the molecular sieve skeleton will be collapsed to a certain extent, and the crystalline structure will be damaged [9,14,28]; (ii) the active Cu species will be aggregated to form the inactive CuO x clusters, which will result in the pore clogging and the decrease in the specific surface area of the catalyst [9,10]; and (iii) the transformation of the active site. ZCuOH will be transformed to Z2Cu [9,14]. Gao et al. [28] found that the CuO x clusters formed after aging could not be detected by STEM, and their size and location could not be determined. This suggests that they are very small and may be located in CHA pores and channels. And the separated Al and CuO x clusters interact during hydrothermal aging, but the interaction time is much earlier than the formation of CuAl2O4 spinel. The dealumination may lead to the degradation of SSZ-13 molecular sieves, but the mesopores produced by the migration of CuO x clusters should be the ultimate cause of the structural collapse of this catalyst. This also verifies that high Cu content and high Si/Al ratio are detrimental to the hydrothermal stability, since in both cases CuO x is more likely to form in the catalyst. In addition, the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst is very sensitive to the temperature of hydrothermal aging. The hydrothermal aging temperature affects the degree of deactivation of the catalyst, and the higher the temperature, the higher the degree of deactivation of the catalyst [9,14]. Song et al. [14] concluded that the more severe the dealumination of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst with increasing aging temperature, the content of Cu species changed, ZCuOH content decreased monotonically while CuO x content increased monotonically, and the Z2Cu content first increased and then decreased. Gao et al. [28] concluded that at aging temperatures of 600 °C or lower, dealumination is negligible, but at higher temperatures, dealumination becomes more severe. Guan et al. [9] found that when the temperature was higher than 850 °C, the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was completely deactivated. The aging temperature plays a key role in the loss of active Cu species and CuO x formation during hydrothermal aging, which is the main reason for the decrease in catalytic performance. At not too high temperatures (below 800 °C), the extension of aging time does not cause sudden changes in the physicochemical properties of the catalyst. 2.1.4 S poisoning During operation of a motor vehicle engine, combustion of the fuel produces SO2 gas, and the SO2 gas produced can have a toxic effect on the catalyst. In recent years, many scholars have carried out detailed studies on the Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts after S poisoning. The sulfur poisoning of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst significantly reduced its SCR efficiency and oxidation capacity [21]. Although the poisoned sample could be regenerated by high temperature, only part of the SCR performance and a small amount of oxidation efficiency could be recovered [29]. The specific poisoning and regeneration mechanism is shown in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that the effect of SO2 on the catalyst is the occupation of active sites and the blockage of pores. From the above, it is known that Z2Cu, ZCuOH, CuO x and Si-O(H)-Al bonds exist on the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst, and S poisoning affects these sites differently. The Z2Cu sites are more resistant to SO2 poisoning compared to the ZCuOH sites, and it is also easier to regenerate after poisoning. Jangjou et al. [30] revealed the poisoning and regeneration mechanism of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts, Z2Cu and ZCuOH, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The S poisoning on the Z2Cu is more moderate, and after the doping of SO2 gas in the NH3-SCR reaction gas, NH3 and SO2 adsorbed on the Z2Cu sites will form (NH4)2SO4, which will then block the pores. Note that SO2 is adsorbed only when it is co-entrained with ammonia [30]. In addition, (NH4)2SO4 will also preferably attach to the ZCuOH sites of untransferred copper sulfate, which will accelerate catalyst deactivation [29]. In addition, when water is present in the gas feed, SO2 uptake is greater [29], poisoning is increased, and deactivation is more severe. SO2 adsorption onto ZCuOH sites results in the formation of CuHSO3. CuHSO3 is very stable and cannot be completely removed even at regeneration temperatures as high as 850 °C. However, with increasing temperature, CuHSO3 can be oxidized to form CuHSO4 species in the presence of O2 [30]. The main role of CuO x is to oxidize SO2 to produce SO3, which leads to the formation of sulphate, which is formed on other sites such as the ZCuOH sites, although sulphate is not formed on CuO x . The type of sulfate affects the pore structure, but (NH4)2SO4 on Z2Cu sites is more likely to cause pore plugging than metal sulfates on ZCuOH sites. On Brønsted acid sites, SO2 forms sulfuric acid, leading to a reduction in acidic sites. And when the gas feed does not contain NH3, the ZCuOH sites are more prone to sulfur poisoning than the Brønsted acid sites. During the regeneration of sulfur poisoning of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst, (NH4)2SO4 generated on Z2Cu can be desulfurized by high-temperature decomposition, which consists of two main steps, firstly, it decomposes to NH3 and NH4HSO4 at temperatures up to 310 °C, and then as the increase in temperature, NH4HSO4 species continue to decompose into NH3 and SO2 [21]. Cu-SSZ-13, which has a relatively high content of ZCuOH sites, requires a higher desulfurization temperature (> 550 °C) compared to Z2Cu. In addition, the CuO x sites in Cu-SSZ-13 undergo an ion exchange reaction to form more Cu ion sites [30]. Therefore, SO2 poisoning after regeneration is able to hinder the non-selective oxidation of NH3 in Cu-SSZ-13 samples by CuO x clusters [29]. Shih et al. [31] found that after the same sulfidation treatment, more SO2-derived intermediates were generated on the ZCuOH site compared to the Z2Cu site, and SO2-derived species were also observed in other areas, leading to blockage of micropores. The apparent activation energy of Z2Cu and ZCuOH samples remained largely unaffected. Z2Cu and ZCuOH can absorb 1-2 hydrogen sulfate (HSO4) species, and when HSO4 is formed at the Z2Cu site, a proton is released from the Brønsted acid site. Furthermore, a Cu site bound to one HSO4 species remains immobile, while a Cu site bound to two HSO4 species is liberated from the framework and becomes more mobile. Brookshear et al. [32] observed the presence of ammonium sulfate as well as the formation of ammonium nitrate. The observed deactivation of low-temperature SCR performance is attributed to the formation of ammonium nitrate below 250 °C and the loss of active Cu sites due to the presence of sulfur in the catalyst. SO2 poisoning leads to the formation of copper hydrogen sulfate species. These species severely deactivate the standard SCR reaction at low temperatures, resulting in fewer available sites for subsequent steps in the SCR reaction. The reduction of SO2-poisoned Cu sites leads to the formation of Cu+ quasi-linear complexes. In poisoned catalysts, copper is further reduced to the metallic state, which is partially blocked, and the migration of Cu ions is low [33]. Regarding regeneration under different conditions, studies have found that even with regeneration by heating in an inert atmosphere and subsequently maintaining oxidative conditions, the copper species are not reversed to their original state but can improve denitrification activity. Regeneration under reducing and inert conditions is more favorable for catalyst denitrification, effectively removing ammonium sulfate from the catalyst without converting it into more stable metal sulfates [34]. In addition to the presence of ammonium sulfate, the formation of ammonium nitrate was also observed. The observed deactivation of low-temperature SCR performance is attributed to the formation of ammonium nitrate below 250 °C and the loss of active Cu sites due to the presence of sulfur in the catalyst. SO2 poisoning leads to the formation of copper hydrogen sulfate species. These species severely deactivate the standard SCR reaction at low temperatures, resulting in fewer available sites for subsequent steps in the SCR reaction. The reduction of SO2-poisoned Cu sites leads to the formation of Cu+ quasi-linear complexes. In poisoned catalysts, copper is further reduced to the metallic state, which is partially blocked, and the migration of Cu ions is low [33]. Regarding regeneration under different conditions, studies have found that even with regeneration by heating in an inert atmosphere and subsequently maintaining oxidative conditions, the copper species are not reversed to their original state but can improve denitrification activity. Regeneration under reducing and inert conditions is more favorable for catalyst denitrification, effectively removing ammonium sulfate from the catalyst without converting it into more stable metal sulfates [34]. In addition to the presence of ammonium sulfate, the formation of ammonium nitrate was also observed. The observed deactivation of low-temperature SCR performance is attributed to the formation of ammonium nitrate below 250 °C and the loss of active Cu sites due to the presence of sulfur in the catalyst. SO2 poisoning leads to the formation of copper hydrogen sulfate species. These species severely deactivate the standard SCR reaction at low temperatures, resulting in fewer available sites for subsequent steps in the SCR reaction. The reduction of SO2-poisoned Cu sites leads to the formation of Cu+ quasi-linear complexes. In poisoned catalysts, copper is further reduced to the metallic state, which is partially blocked, and the migration of Cu ions is low [33]. Regarding regeneration under different conditions, studies have found that even with regeneration by heating in an inert atmosphere and subsequently maintaining oxidative conditions, the copper species are not reversed to their original state but can improve denitrification activity. Regeneration under reducing and inert conditions is more favorable for catalyst denitrification, effectively removing ammonium sulfate from the catalyst without converting it into more stable metal sulfates [34]. Xi et al. [35] investigated the effect of hydrothermal aging on the catalyst resistance to S poisoning. After hydrothermal aging, the SCR reactivity of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was reduced, and the activity would be further reduced by continuing the sulfidation treatment. However, prior to the sulfidation treatment, the decrease in SCR reactivity decreases with increasing aging time and the catalyst becomes more resistant to sulfur poisoning. This is due to the gradual conversion of ZCuOH to Z2Cu in the catalyst with the increase of aging time, which in turn improves the S poisoning resistance of the catalyst. 2.1.5 P poisoning P poisoning adversely affects the activity and hydrothermal stability of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. P poisoning leads to a decrease in the NH3 oxidation conversion of the catalyst, resulting in an increase in high temperature SCR activity due to increased selectivity. At low temperatures (< 200 °C), the NH3-SCR activity of mildly poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 decreased slightly, while the NH3-SCR activity of heavily poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 decreased significantly. Scholars have made a thorough study on the mechanism of P poisoning deactivation of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 11, Chen et al. [36] concluded that the introduction of phosphorus on Cu-SSZ-13 resulted in the following changes: (i) partial pore blockage and decrease in the specific surface area of the catalyst; (ii) dealumination of the molecular sieve skeleton and decrease in Brønsted acidic sites; (iii) phosphorus-copper interactions leading to a decrease in Cu oxides and Z2Cu. The loss of the active species in the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst is the root cause of catalyst deactivation. Comparison with S poisoning reveals that there are also similarities between them. For example, ZCuOH is less tolerant and P is more inclined to interact with ZCuOH compared to Z2Cu. Guo et al. [37] found that phosphorus poisoning (especially at high phosphorus loading) also inhibited the Cu site redox cycle (CuII↔CuI), and in particular, the CuI→CuII re-oxidation half-cycle was markedly inhibited due to the inhibition by P poisoning of the formation of the intermediate Cu dimer. Researchers have also scrutinized the Z2Cu and ZCuOH sites on Cu-SSZ-13, and the relevant poisoning mechanisms are shown in Fig. 9. Wang et al. [38] found that P poisoning of the Z2Cu site involves two P atoms, which generates P2O5, but poisoning of the ZCuOH site requires only one P atom (PO3 −) or less (PO4 3−) [38] (Fig. 8 ). Therefore, in Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts containing a higher number of ZCuOH sites, less phosphorus poisoning would achieve the same deactivation. The generated P2O5 will cover the Z2Cu sites, while PO3 − or PO4 3− will form related complexes with ZCuOH [38]. Phosphorus content has a certain effect on P poisoning of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. Chen et al. [36] found that the acidic structure, acidic sites and Cu2+ active sites of the catalyst did not change greatly at low phosphorus content, and phosphorus will reduce CuO x , which lowers the negative effect of CuO x oxidation of NH3 at high temperatures, and improves the conversion efficiency of the catalyst at high temperatures; when the phosphorus content reaches 0.4 mmol/g, the catalyst will show the previously mentioned changes, including a significant reduction of acidic sites and Cu2+, and the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst is also decreased. Wang et al. [38] investigated the effect of P poisoning on the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. It was found that the P-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst experienced more severe dealumination after high-temperature hydrothermal aging at 900 °C, resulting in more severe catalyst deactivation. Phosphorus reacted with aluminum to form AlPO4, which accelerated the catalyst structure collapse. And the formation of AlPO4 had a highly linear relationship with the ZCuOH/Z2Cu ratio. In addition, the deactivation was more severe when the Cu content was higher. The ZCuOH-phosphate/metaphosphate complexes detached more easily from the framework during severe aging than the Z2Cu-P2O5 species. The mechanism of P-poisoning of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was mentioned above, which is similar to that of its S-poisoning, both including the reduction of active sites and the destruction of the catalyst structure (Fig. 10 ). Therefore, it is not difficult to deduce that the S tolerance of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst decreases after P poisoning. This was also demonstrated by Chen et al. [36] who found that in the presence of SO2, the NO conversion of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst decreases dramatically below 350 °C with the increase of phosphorus loading. And the specific surface area, acid sites and active Cu2+ ions of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst after P poisoning were further reduced after sulfur poisoning, especially active Cu2+ ions [36]. The P-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst can be regenerated by washing with hot water [39]. The specific operation [39] is as follows: first, the poisoned catalyst is mixed with 100g of deionized water. Then, the suspension was stirred and refluxed at 90 °C for several days. After separation, washing with deionized water, and drying at 110 °C, the regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was obtained. Fig. 11 reveals the mechanism of hot water washing to regenerate P-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. During the regeneration of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst, three main changes occurred: (i) the porosity increase of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was improved, and the phosphorus that blocked the pores was removed; (ii) the acidic sites in the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst were basically restored, and Al's of the molecular sieve skeleton bound to P could be reconverted to the classical skeleton aluminum during the washing process, forming Si-OH-Al groups; (iii) the number of active Cu2+ ions increased, some of the copper phosphate/copper metaphosphate dissolved or decomposed, and the inactivated Cu2+ ions were restored and redistributed. Although the catalytic performance and hydrothermal stability were largely recovered after regeneration of the poisoned catalyst (0.3 mmol/g), the activity of the poisoned catalyst could not be completely regenerated, especially the low-temperature performance. This is because the deactivation of Cu2+ ions in the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst can be divided into reversible and irreversible deactivation, and only reversibly deactivated Cu2+ ions can be regenerated. In addition, most of the phosphorus is decomposed during the high temperature hydrothermal aging treatment. Therefore, high-temperature hydrothermal aging treatment after hot water washing can better restore the SCR performance of phosphorus-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. 2.1.7 Alkali and alkaline earth metal poisoning In Section 2.2.1, it was mentioned that alkali washing can enhance the SCR catalytic performance of Cu-SSZ-13. Alkali and alkaline earth metal co-cations have a promoting effect on the catalyst. In the following discussion, I will provide a brief additional explanation. Coordinating cations weaken the interaction between Cu ions and the CHA framework, causing Cu ions to reside deeper in the CHA cages and become more readily reducible. Li+ and Na+ co-cations promote the low-temperature SCR activity by modifying the redox properties and positions of the Cu active sites. They do not hinder the migration of Cu2+ ions to energetically favorable positions but limit the number of Cu2+ ions at these positions to varying extents. Additionally, some Cu2+ ions undergo hydrolysis and self-reduction to form Cu+, reducing the number of Brønsted acid sites and improving the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13. On the other hand, larger-sized co-cations such as K+ and Cs+ decrease the catalytic activity by blocking the pores of the catalyst. At higher reaction temperatures, these co-cations reduce the adsorption capacity of NH3 on the catalyst, leading to a decrease in NO conversion rates [40]. While alkali and alkaline earth metal co-cations have a promoting effect, they can also have negative impacts on the catalyst's performance. Some researchers have found that the NH3-SCR activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts were significantly reduced after alkali and alkaline earth metal poisoning [27,41]. The effects of alkali or alkaline earth metals on Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts were loss of active sites and destruction of zeolite structure, with the former being the main cause of deactivation. The Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst is resistant to alkali/alkaline earth metals in has a certain degree of resistance. Fan et al. [27] found that after impregnation with a certain amount of alkali/alkaline earth metals (0.50 mmol/g), the specific surface area of the catalysts, the active Cu2+ ions and the zeolite acidity remained basically unchanged. However, after the introduction of a high content of alkali metals (1.50 mmol/g), the Cu-SSZ-13 NH3-SCR activity of the catalyst was greatly reduced, the zeolite structure was severely deteriorated, and some of the active Cu2+ ions were converted to CuO x [27]. Cui et al. [19] also suggested that excessive alkali metal co-cations destabilize the ZCuOH sites and promote the formation of harmful CuO x species during catalyst aging. Wang et al. [42] attributed the decrease in NH3-SCR activity of Na-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 in the low temperature range to the loss of active Cu2+ ions, whereas they attributed the decrease in activity at high temperatures to the decrease in active Cu species and acid sites as well as the production of CuO x . Alkali metals (Na+, K+) deactivate the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst by the same mechanism, but they cause different degrees of deactivation [41]. K poisoning samples deactivate more severely, and due to the fact that K+ has a much smaller hydration diameter and stronger binding capacity, K+ can enter the CHA framework and exchange with the acid sites more easily. Therefore, when Na+ and K+ coexist, the deactivation is mainly caused by K+. Liu et al.[43] investigated the effect of different potassium species on the NH3-SCR activity of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. The deactivation effects of potassium salts were in the order of K2CO3 > K2SO4 > K3PO4. Cui et al. [19] found that the co-cation of Ca2+ was detrimental at any loading, and it even destroyed the otherwise highly stable Z2Cu active site. Fan et al. [27] loaded alkali or alkaline-earth metal on fresh Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts by the incipient wet impregnation method elements (K, Ca, Na and Mg) on fresh Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts by primary wet impregnation and compared the degree of deactivation of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts by different alkali or alkaline earth metals, and the deactivation effects were in the following order: Mg > Ca > Na > K. At the same metal loading, the impregnation of Mg and Ca caused more severe damage to the zeolite structure, and had a greater effect on the distribution of Cu2+/Cu+ within the catalyst than that of K and Na. In addition, Mg2+ has a smaller diameter, which can displace active Cu2+ ions at the exchange sites more easily and lead to the formation of CuO x clusters outside the zeolite framework. From this, it is easy to conclude that alkaline earth metals are more toxic to the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. In addition, they investigated the combined effects of alkali metal poisoning and hydrothermal aging on the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. The results showed that Cu-SSZ-13 could withstand the simultaneous treatment of alkali metal poisoning (0.5 mmol/gcat.) and hydrothermal aging (aging at 700 °C for 12 h) to a certain extent. Wang et al. [41] also investigated the effects of Na+ and K+ on the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. The deactivation mechanism of alkali metal ions under hydrothermal aging is shown in Fig. 12 . It is mainly reflected in the reduction of acid sites and the collapse of CHA skeleton, which irreversibly weakened the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13 and degraded the NH3-SCR performance. Under mild hydrothermal aging (≤700 °C), alkali metal ions enter the pores of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst and exchange with acidic sites, resulting in a decrease in the acidic sites and the content of active Cu ions in the catalyst, and Cu is converted to inactive CuO x , and the degree of conversion increases with the increase of alkali content and hydrothermal temperature. When the alkali content and hydrothermal temperature are increased to a sufficiently high level (≥1.0 mmol/g, > 700 °C), there is also an effect on the skeleton in the form of a decrease in crystallinity and the formation of new phases (SiO2) and new copper species (CuAlO x ). Thus, during hydrothermal aging, alkali metals cause desilication of SSZ-13 and formation of H2Si2O5 and CuO x crystals. Jia et al. [44] employed a hydrothermal-induced self-assembly process, designed and fabricated a bifunctional core−shell structural Cu-SSZ-13@Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 (Cu-SSZ-13@CZO) catalysts with excellent co-resistance to SO2 and K+ poisoning. The catalyst exhibited high SCR activity even after treatment with 10 vol % H2O and 200 ppm SO2 for 12 h, followed by impregnation with 1.0 wt% K+. The CZO shell layer can act as a sacrificial site to trap SO2 to form sulfate, and the sulfate traps K+. preventing Cu2+ from being destroyed. In addition, the CZO shell layer can provide additional Brønsted acid sites to promote NO x adsorption and activation. Thus, the CZO shell layer has a dual function to effectively prevent SO2 and K+ from poisoning the active Cu ions of the catalyst. 2.2 Cu-SAPO-34 2.2.1 Preparation Cu-SAPO-34 is recognized as one of the best catalysts with good NH3-SCR performance, high N2 selectivity and excellent high temperature hydrothermal stability, but its low temperature hydrothermal stability needs to be improved. Cu-SAPO-34 has been developed in recent years with many kinds of new preparation methods. Ion exchange method, impregnation method and one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method are commonly used for the synthesis of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts[45]. Fan et al. [46] synthesized Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts by using precipitation, ion exchange and one-pot methods, and found that Cu in the precipitated samples was dominated by CuO x clusters, and that Cu in the ion-exchanged samples was dominated by Cu2+, and in the catalysts synthesized by one-pot method, the CuO x and Cu2+ were present simultaneously. Li et al. [47] prepared two Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with identical Cu loading using Cu-TEPA as a co-template by ion-exchange (IE) and one-pot synthesis (OP) methods. It was found that the one-pot synthesized sample had the highest active Cu2+ ions, while the ion-exchanged sample had more surface CuO x particles and internal CuO x nanoparticles. Apparently, the one-pot synthesis method is favorable for the uniform dispersion of Cu species. Wang et al. [48] also found that the catalysts synthesized using the one-pot method of Cu-SAPO-34 possessed a complete cubic structure, a wide temperature window, and a high SCR reaction activity characteristics. During the synthesis process, the temperature and time of hydrothermal treatment had a significant effect on the Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, and when the hydrothermal temperature was higher than 150 °C and the hydrothermal time was greater than 3 d, the Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with cubic structure could be obtained with higher catalyst activity. Niu et al. [49] also synthesized Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts by using one-pot synthesis method, and found that a higher calcination temperature (700 °C) was favorable for the catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34, and too high (800 °C) temperature had a detrimental effect. The Cu source did not have a significant effect on the catalytic performance of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, but the Cu content would have a negative effect on the stability and catalytic activity of Cu-SAPO-34, with a high Cu content detrimental to the hydrothermal stability, and a low Cu content is unfavorable to the catalytic activity[49]. Xiang et al. [50] found that the stability of the SAPO-34 backbone structure was enhanced with the increase of Cu content, and the structure and acidic sites of the catalyst could be well preserved, but the high Cu content also exacerbated the formation of CuO x during hydrothermal treatment. Tang et al. [51] analyzed that the hydrothermal treatment of the highly loaded Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts at 950 °C resulted in the Si-OH-Al bond breakage of the molecular sieve carrier, as shown in Fig. 13 . Si content has an effect on the catalytic performance and stability of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts. Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with lower Si content have good low-temperature hydrothermal stability [52,53], while Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with higher Si content have better SCR catalytic performance. Lin et al. [52] prepared Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts using Cu-TEAOH (with high Si content) which had a better hydrothermal stability than that of Cu-TEA (with low Si content), and Petitto et al. [53] also found that Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with low Si content had good hydrothermal stability. Yu et al. [54] further found that the amount of Si species in the gel and the type of template could regulate the amount of acid sites on SAPO-34, which correlated with the activity of Cu-SAPO-34. Cao et al. [55] found that with the increase in Si content in Cu-SAPO-34 increases, the Brønsted acid sites content remain essentially the same, but the proportion of Si islands increases and the Si(4Al) species decreases, leading to an increase in acid strength. Chen et al. [56] found that the Si coordination environment in Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts can be modulated by the addition of Si precursors. More Si islands (Si(0OAl)) and less isolated Si(Si(4OAl)) were generated in Cu-SAPO-34 when more Si precursors were added to the initial gel. Wang et al. [57] found that hydrothermal treatment could change the Si coordination structure, and the specific process is shown in Fig. 14 . The organic template for the synthesis of SAPO-34 affects the catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts. Morpholine (MOR) is considered to be a cheaper SDA for the synthesis of high yield SAPO-34 zeolites, but the low-temperature hydrothermal stability of SAPO-34 zeolites synthesized by it is not very good[58]. Wang et al. [48] concluded that Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts prepared by using TEPA as an SDA can maintain high crystal integrity and active sites, which is favorable for SCR reaction. Woo et al. [58] found that the SCR performance of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts prepared with triethylamine (TEA) and tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH) as templating agents recovered most of their SCR performance after low-temperature hydrothermal aging regeneration, whereas Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts prepared with morpholine (MOR) as a templating agent regenerated only partially recovered their activity after low-temperature hydrothermal aging. Yu et al. [54] found that the TEA and TEAOH templates tended to form more Si islands compared to MA and DEA. The Cu2+ species in Cu/TEA and Cu/TEAOH had fewer Cu species and more CuO x species than Cu/MA and Cu/DEA due to the presence of Si islands. Zhang et al. [59] used different SDAs (DEA, TEA, PA and TEAOH), different SDAs (DEA, TEA, PA and TEAOH) were used to prepare Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with similar copper loading by the "one-pot method", and the effects of the different SDAs on the NO x conversion and low-temperature hydrothermal stability were investigated. The fresh catalysts were all highly active, and the order of activity for NH3-SCR was: DEA > TEA > PA > TEAOH. while the order of activity of the aged catalysts was reversed after the hydrothermal treatment at 80 °C. Du et al. [60] concluded that the use of PA as a template could help the Cu-SAPO-34 to obtain more active Cu2+ ions and strong acid sites, the and resulted in a higher Si content in the catalyst. Cu-SAPO-34 prepared with PA as template showed excellent catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability under low/high temperature conditions, which is a suitable template agent for the synthesis of Cu-SAPO-34 (one-pot method). Overall, the influence of template agents on the catalyst structure and performance is mainly reflected in the Si content and Si coordination. SAPO-34 zeolite is different from SSZ-13 in that the former also contains P element. Therefore, the P/Al ratio also has an effect on the performance of the catalyst. The P/Al ratio mainly affects the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst and enhances with the increase of the P/Al ratio, whereas it has little effect on the catalytic activity and S-resistance of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst[61]. The promotional effect of P on Cu-SAPO-34 is shown in Fig. 15 . It is not difficult to find that P stabilizes the structure of the catalyst, improves the crystallinity of the catalyst, and increases the grain size of the catalyst, and the large grain size of Cu-SAPO-34 also facilitates the conversion of CuO x to active Cu2+ ions and inhibits the aggregation of Cu species. In addition, the increased surface area and micropores of the high-P Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst facilitated the dispersion of Cu2+ ions and enhanced the adsorption of gaseous reactants. Also, more acid sites are provided, so the catalyst has good hydrothermal stability. He et al. [62] obtained Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with SO4 2− coordinating copper ions by impregnating copper sulfate precursor on SAPO-34, which exhibited excellent SCR performance and SO2 resistance. In the SCR feed with high concentration of SO2, more than 90% NO conversion was maintained after 24 h of reaction. This is because in the SO4 2−-coordinated Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst, the directional coordination of SO4 2− on the Cu site reduces the adsorption of SO2, which in turn reduces the deposition of ammonium bisulfite species (ABS) and inhibits the sulfation of the Cu active site. This SO4 2−-coordinated Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst was able to perform a complete SCR reaction cycle under SO2 poisoning, which was a result of the well-maintained reduction-re-oxidation process at the Cu active sites. He et al. [63] synthesized Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts by one-pot synthesis using aluminum phosphate as the phosphorus and aluminum source and Cu-TEPA to form an initial gel. The Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst synthesized by this method showed superior NH3-SCR catalytic activity at high temperatures compared to the conventional Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst synthesized using phosphoric acid as the phosphorus source. 2.2.2 Structure and active site SAPO-34 is a structural analog of zeolite hematite (CHA), a crystalline silica-aluminum phosphate. The framework consists of a D6R (double six-membered ring) connected by a tilted four-membered ring, for example to form the hexagonally stacked layer ABCABC. As shown in Fig. 16 , SAPO-34 molecular sieve is mainly composed of four elements, Si, P, Al, and O, which are formed by the substitution of Si into the backbone of aluminum phosphate (AlPO4), where the atoms of Al, P, and Si occupy four of the structural coordination positions in the structure, each connected to four oxygen atoms[64]. The backbone structure is mainly formed by PO4, AlO4 and SiO4 tetrahedra interconnected to form a tripartite crystal system, the specific surface area can reach more than 500m2/g, the pore volume is 0.42 cm3/g, the pore size is between 0.43 and 0.50 nm, and the surface is electronegative, forming the shape of a cube. SAPO-34 zeolites have a very stable crystal structure, and Watanabe et al. [65] found that the microporous structure of SAPO-34 remained stable at 1000 °C. The distribution of Cu species is the focus of the study of the catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34. Cu species in Cu-SAPO-34, including CuO x , Cu2+ and Cu+, have been reported[66]. Cu2+ ions are the active site for the NH3-SCR reaction, while surface CuO x particles promote the side reaction (NH3 oxidation is promoted at >350 °C). Wang et al. [67] explored the active site of Cu-SAPO-34, who used different synthesis methods to obtain Cu-SAPO-34 samples containing different Cu species, and found that only Cu2+ ions are catalytic for the SCR reaction, and Cu species in the oxidized state are not catalytic. The positions where the Cu ions are present are shown in Fig. 17 , and there are four possibilities: position I is located inside the octet ring, near the center of symmetry of the hexagonal prism; position II is located near the center of the ellipsoidal cavity; position III is located at the center of the hexagonal prism; and position IV is located near the window of the octet ring. Xue et al. [68] have explored the Cu-SAPO-34 active sites were determined in more depth, and through the active component-kinetics correlation, they found that not all Cu2+ were active, and that the isolated state Cu2+ species at position I was the active center of the low-temperature (100∼200 °C) NH3-SCR reaction. Wang et al. [67] showed that the Cu2+ and CuO x species in the Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts separation increased with increasing Cu loading. Zhang et al. [59] found that Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with more Si-O(H)-Al bonds, more ZCuOH, and fewer CuO x clusters had higher SCR catalytic activity and N2 selectivity. Unlike the Brønsted acid sites in SSZ-13, the formation of Brønsted acid sites in SAPO-34 molecular sieves is generated by Si by substituting P in the aluminum phosphate structure [69,70], and it may also substitute both P and Al to form Si-O-Si. In addition, the Si coordination structure has a significant effect on the catalytic performance and durability. Chen et al. [56] found that high contents of Si(4OAl) and Si(0OAl) were detrimental to the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts. However, the Si(xOAl) (x=1∼3) structure facilitated the stabilization of Cu2+ ions, thus enhancing the stability against vigorous hydrothermal treatment. They prepared ultra-stable Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with appropriate Si content ([Si/Al + P] = 0.210) and high content (50.2%) of Si(xOAl) (x = 1∼3) structure, which still possessed 90% NO reduction efficiency in the range of 200∼450 °C after high-temperature hydrothermal aging at 850 °C. Yu et al. [54] and found that the Si(xOAl) (x=1∼3) structures could produce more strong acid sites. Cao et al. [55] found that the content of Brønsted acid sites remained essentially the same with the increase of Si content in Cu-SAPO-34, but the Si(xOAl) (x=1∼3) structures increased and the Si(4Al) species decreased. In addition, the Si(4Al)-rich Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts have better SCR activity as shown in Fig. 18 . Therefore, the distribution of Si determines the acid strength and content of SAPO-34, leading to a significant distribution of Cu, which affects the catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34. Different Si coordination structures in SAPO-34 have different acid properties. In the low-temperature range, the different acid properties have little effect on the activity of NH3-SCR on Cu-SAPO-34 samples, and the conversion of NO is mainly affected by the acid density. Grain size has been reported to have an impact on the stability of catalysts. Xu et al. [71] prepared Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with different grain sizes and found that the small grain size was favorable for the catalytic activity, but the activity of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts was enhanced by the large grain size after hydrothermal treatment. There are two reasons for this, one is that the larger the grain size, the more severe the oxygen diffusion limitation, and the regenerated Cu2+ is more active after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment, and the other is that a great number of regenerated Cu2+ species prevents Si-O-Al hydrolysis and maintains the integrity of the SAPO-34 zeolite framework. 2.2.3 Hydrothermal aging properties Compared to Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SAPO-34 has poorer low-temperature hydrothermal stability and better high-temperature hydrothermal stability. It was found that Cu-SAPO-34 undergoes partially irreversible backbone degradation during preparation or when exposed to low-temperature moisture[72], whereas SSZ-13 does not undergo such degradation at all. The overall SCR catalytic performance of fresh Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts decreased after low-temperature hydrothermal aging. Leistner et al. [73] showed that low-temperature hydrothermal aging lowered the molecular sieve pore volume and substantially reduced the Cu active sites involved in NH3-SCR redox. Wang et al. [74] found that most of the Si-O-Al bonds of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst were destroyed after hydrothermal aging at 70 °C, and the Z2Cu sites could inhibit this phenomenon, as shown in Fig. 19 . Wang et al. [75] suggested that during the low-temperature hydrothermal aging of the Si-O(H)-Al undergoes hydrolysis to form Al(H2O)3. The ZCuOH sites also undergo hydrolysis to form Cu(OH)2. Cao et al. [31] suggested that after low-temperature hydrothermal treatment, the low-acid Si species (Si(4Al)) transforms into the same species as the more acidic Si species (Si(3Al), Si(2Al), or Si(1Al)) or the acid-free of Si(0Al) (Fig. 16). Thus Si(4Al)-rich Cu-SAPO-34 with lower Si content has better hydrothermal stability. Ma et al. [76] emphasized the key role of Cu(OH)2 in low-temperature wet degradation of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, where the terminal Al(H2O)3 partially traps Cu(OH)2 leading to the irreversible deactivation of the ZCuOH. Jiang et al. [77] found that after low-temperature hydrothermal aging treatment of Cu-SAPO-34, both copper ions and CuO x species were reduced, and two new copper oxide substances, CuAl2O4 and Al-rich CuO x clusters, were formed, with reduced reducibility. Zhang et al. [59] concluded that the low-temperature hydrothermal aging mechanism of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst was developed and the results are shown in Fig. 20 . The effects of low-temperature hydrothermal aging on the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst are as follows: (i) the active ZCuOH separates from the CHA cation sites and aggregates into inactive CuO x clusters, which reduces its low-temperature catalytic activity; (ii) hydrolysis of Si-O(H)-Al occurs, the loss of the strong acidic site, and the growth of CuO x clusters, which results in the decrease of the high-temperature catalytic performance. Therefore, it is not difficult to find that low-temperature hydrothermal aging mainly destroys Brønsted acid sites and ZCuOH sites. However, the hydrolysis (reversible inactivation) occurring at the Si-O(H)-Al sites can be regenerated at conditions higher than 100 °C, and therefore, the activity of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst inactivated by low-temperature hydrothermal aging can be somewhat restored. Among them, reversible hydrolysis produces Al(H2O)3 and irreversible hydrolysis forms Si-O-Si structure[78]. Ma et al. [79] found that P-O-Al also hydrolyzes to produce terminal P-OH/Al-OH and extra-framework phosphates, but the strongly adsorbed NH4 + protects the P-O-Al and Si-O(H)-Al bonds from hydrolysis, which, in turn, enhances the low-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34. Wang et al. [75] reported that low-temperature hydrolysis of the Cu active center and Brønsted acid sites could be effectively prevented by saturated ammonia adsorption during catalyst pretreatment. Cu-SAPO-34 has excellent high-temperature hydrothermal aging properties, and Wang et al. [80] found that under the same hydrothermal aging conditions (800 °C, 10% H2O, 16 h), the NH3-SCR activity of Cu-SSZ-13 was severely decreased whereas Cu-SAPO-34 still maintained excellent catalytic activity. The NH3-SCR catalytic activity of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst was reported to be increased after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment [46,81]. The activity of the catalyst is related to the number of active species, the integrity of the catalyst structure and the acid site content. Gao et al. [78] found that the aging treatment produces more Si-O-Si structures in the CHA structure, but the CHA structure is still retained. From the previous section, it is known that the Cu species in Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts are Cu2+, Cu+ and CuO x . Scholars have done a lot of studies on the changes of Cu species in Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts after high temperature hydrothermal aging. Tian et al. [81] concluded that the CuO x bodies were converted to Cu2+ active components (Z2Cu and ZCuOH) with better dispersion. Jiang et al. [77] found that Cu-SAPO-34 showed more extra-framework Al and CuO x clusters after high-temperature hydrothermal aging treatment, forming abundant aggregated CuO x clusters and a few Al-rich CuO x clusters. Li et al. [47] studied fresh Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts after hydrothermal treatment at 750 °C for 16 h. It was found that the internal CuO x nanosites were rapidly transformed into active Cu2+ ions, followed by a slow transformation into surface CuO x particles. Liu et al. [82] found that high-temperature hydrothermal treatment yielded more active Cu2+ ions and Lewis acid sites, and that with the increase of Cu loading, the number of active Cu2+ ions and surface CuO x clusters increased. The main mechanism is shown in Fig. 21 , where the surface CuO x is converted to active Cu2+ ions and inactive CuO x clusters. Therefore, it is not difficult to find that due to the increase of active Cu species and acid sites, the low-temperature activity of Cu-SAPO-34 increases after hydrothermal aging, while the NO x conversion decreases at high temperature. Although the high-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 is very good and there is an increase in activity after hydrothermal treatment, it is still deactivated at very high temperatures. Fan et al. [83] found that the activity of the catalyst was significantly decreased by hydrothermal treatment of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts at 950 °C, and the deactivation was more serious with the increase of time, and the catalyst was almost inactive (Fig. 22 ). The following changes mainly occurred in Cu-SAPO-34: the crystallinity of molecular sieves decreased at 3h of treatment time; the molecular sieve crystals were transformed into SiO2 and AlPO4 phases after 6h; and the Si-OH-Al bond was broken after 12h, and the number of Brønsted acidic sites decreased. The deactivation mechanism is shown in Fig. 22, (i) SiO2 and AlPO4 phases were generated, leading to irreversible skeleton collapse; (ii) Si-OH-Al bond hydrolyzed and broken, and the number of Brønsted acidic sites decreased; and (iii) the coordination environment of the reactive Cu species was destroyed, and the shape generated Cu/SiO2 was less reactive. The effect of P/Al ratio on Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts was mentioned previously, and it is not difficult to know that P promotes the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, but it has little effect on the activity of the catalysts. However, the P-modified Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts not only showed increased catalytic activity but also enhanced stability after hydrothermal treatment[81]. Tian et al. [81] loaded PO4 3− onto fresh Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts by impregnation method, and found that the activity of the catalysts was increased after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment activity was further enhanced. The introduction of phosphate ions increases the Brønsted acid sites and further promotes the dispersion of the Cu active component. Therefore, the introduction of phosphate ions helps to increase the activity of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst (Fig. 23 ). In summary, both low-temperature hydrothermal aging and severe high-temperature hydrothermal aging after aging adversely affect the NH3-SCR catalytic activity of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, whereas less severe high-temperature hydrothermal aging has a promotional effect on the activity of Cu-SAPO-34. 2.2.4 S poisoning SO x produced by elemental sulfur in fuels after combustion at high temperatures causes catalyst deactivation, especially low-temperature activity [84,85]. Wijayanti et al. [85] investigated the effect of sulfidation treatment on Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, and showed that the surface area, pores, and surface acidity of the catalysts were reduced to a certain extent by sulfidation treatment, and the catalysts produced copper sulfate on their surfaces. Shen et al. [86] found that active Cu2+ ions may be converted to copper sulfate/copper sulfite upon SO2 poisoning. Hammershøi et al. [84] showed by DFT calculations that the reason for catalyst deactivation caused by SO2 is mainly related to the reduction of Cu sites. In Cu-SAPO-34 and Cu-SSZ-13, the interaction of S species with Cu is similar, SO2 binds better to Cu(I), while SO3 binds stronger to Cu(II) (Fig. 24 ), and SO3 may be formed by the oxidation of SO2 on Cu sites. Jangjou et al. [87] suggested that at low temperatures NH3 favors the Cu-SAPO-34 adsorption of SO2 to form ammonia sulfate, whereas under NH3-free conditions only CuSO4 species were present. He et al. [62] found that the reduction of CuII species to CuI and the re-oxidation of CuI species to CuII is usually inhibited after poisoning of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst SO2, which leads to the accumulation of ABS and sulfation of Cu sites (Fig. 25 ). The temperature of the sulfidation treatment also has an effect on the catalyst, Shen et al. [88] found that at 150∼300 °C the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst had a decrease in the amount of active Cu2+ ions after SO3 poisoning, and at temperatures higher than 300 °C the decrease in activity was due to a decrease in the amount of active Cu2+ ions and the formation of aluminium sulphide by the breakage of the Si-O(H)-Al bond (Fig. 26 ). Hammershøi et al. [84] found that the low-temperature (< 200 °C) activity of Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts was even lower and irreversibly deactivated to a greater extent after S poisoning. Zhang et al. [89] found that the main reason for the deactivation of Cu-SAPO-34 at temperatures lower than 300 °C and in the presence of NH3 was ammonium sulphate species. Ammonium sulfate decomposes at 300∼350 °C, while other sulfur-containing species require higher temperatures (> 480 °C) for desorption. Therefore, deactivation is more severe at lower temperatures. High-temperature treatment attenuates the degree of deactivation of sulfide Cu-SAPO-34. Hammershøi et al. [84] regenerated sulfide-treated Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts at 550 °C and found that the catalyst activity was restored to 80%, and regeneration at 700 °C restored all activity. Shen et al. [90] found that heat treatment does not change the organizational framework of zeolites but increases the amount of active Cu, and the regenerated Cu2+ activity is consistent with the original Cu2+ activity. The related thermal regeneration mechanism is shown in Fig. 27 , where they found that the ammonia sulfate salt was first decomposed and removed at 500 °C, and a part of the poisoned active Cu2+ content was restored, and then the copper sulfate was gradually decomposed with the increase of temperature, and the decomposition was complete at 750 °C. During the decomposition of copper sulfate, the migration of CuO x to Z2Cu until the disappearance of CuO x content, when the temperature is higher than 600 °C, Z2Cu continue to increase. 2.2.5 P poisoning In the previous paper, we analyzed in detail the effect of P poisoning on the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst, which generates P2O5 and PO4 3−, which in turn results in pore clogging and loss of Cu active sites. However, there seems to be some differences in Cu-SAPO-34, firstly, phosphoric acid can be used as a P source for the synthesis of SAPO-34 zeolite, which contains PO4 3−, and phosphoric acid can be toxic to Cu-SSZ-13, and secondly, P2O5 can also be used as a P source. These P species that are unfavorable to Cu-SSZ-13 can nevertheless synthesize SAPO-34 zeolites, so we speculate that appropriate P may have a certain promotion effect on Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts. In recent years, the effect of PO4 3− on Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts has been investigated. Tian et al. [81], mentioned previously, found that PO4 3− could further enhance the denitrification activity of Cu-SAPO-34 after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment. Wang et al. [91] reported that the addition of P increased the number of Z2Cu sites in Cu-SAPO-34, improved the low-temperature (< 250 °C) activity of fresh Cu-SAPO-34 samples and further enhanced the low-temperature activity after high-temperature hydrothermal aging (which increased with increasing P content), but was detrimental to the stability of the zeolite structure. Appropriate P also improves the S resistance of Cu-SAPO-34 and can inhibit the adsorption of SO2 by Cu-SAPO-34. 2.2.6 Alkali and alkaline earth metal poisoning The Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst underwent alkali metal and alkaline earth metal poisoning, and its NH3-SCR activity decreased, but the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism was not affected. Pore clogging, loss of acidic sites and copper active sites have been considered as the main reasons for deactivation by alkali metal/alkaline earth metal poisoning. Wang et al. [92] suggested that the main reasons for deactivation when Na ions were deposited on Cu-SAPO-34 were the reduction of acidic sites on the surface and the loss of active Cu2+ ions. The relevant mechanisms are shown in Fig. 28 : (i) Na+ will exchange ions with acidic sites and Z2Cu sites on Cu-SAPO-34, and the former is easier to carry out; (ii) H+ in Cu-SAPO-34 is exchanged, and the samples are in a localized acidic environment, which results in the formation of new species, such as SiO2 or AlPO4, which then leads to the structural collapse of SAPO-34 zeolites, and crystallinity and specific surface area Yang et al. [72] suggested that the Cu2+/Cu+ ions on Cu-SAPO-34 were replaced by Na and transferred to the neighboring unbonded Al atoms to form CuAlO2 with no SCR activity, leading to a significant decrease in the SCR performance. For different alkali metal species, the poisoning behavior of Cu-SAPO-34 is related to the strength and ionic diameter of the alkali metal[72]. Yang et al. [72] showed experimentally and through DFT calculations that the order of the strength of the poisoning ability is: Li+ < K+ < Na+, K tends to bind to the Si-O(H)-Al site [72,93], while Li and Na are more inclined to bind to active Cu ions (Fig. 29 ). For Cu-SAPO-34, the effects of poisoning due to alkaline earth metals are greater[94]. The content of alkaline metals affects the degree of poisoning, and in general, the higher the content, the more severe the poisoning. Ma et al. [95] found that Cu-SAPO-34 had very good tolerance to K, but its NH3-SCR activity was significantly reduced and its zeolite framework structure was disrupted at high levels of K (2.5 wt%). Wang et al. [92] found that with the increase in the content of Na increased (0.4 wt%, 0.8 wt%, 1.3 wt% and 1.8 wt%), the activity of Cu-SAPO-34 decreased, but the relative reduction was not significant. Albert et al. [94] also concluded that the activity and structure of Cu-SAPO-34 remained intact at low alkali and alkaline-earth-metal contents (0.50 mmol/gcat), but at high contents (1.50 mmol/gcat) conditions, the SAPO-34 zeolite structure was disrupted, and a significant decrease in the SCR performance. Cu-SAPO-34 has superior alkali resistance compared to Cu-SSZ-13. Liu et al. [93] loaded KNO3 onto freshly prepared Cu-SSZ-13 and Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts by impregnation method and found that Cu-SAPO-34 is more potassium tolerant and only slightly deactivated for NH3-SCR in low and high temperature ranges, whereas Cu SSZ-13 was severely deactivated. In real diesel vehicles, NO x catalysts may experience failure by sodium (Na) poisoning, low temperature hydrothermal (LTH) deactivation, and SO2 poisoning during simultaneous selective catalytic reduction (SCR).
