Therefore, it is important to investigate the synergistic effect between S poisoning and Na poisoning in the low-temperature hydrothermal aging of Cu-SAPO-34. Na improves the low-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34, but makes SO2 poisoning more severe[96]. The main reasons are as follows: the ion exchange between Na+ and H+ leads to a decrease in the number of Brønsted acid sites (Si-O(H)-Al), which weakens the hydrolysis of Si-O-Al groups during the LTH process and thus protects the SAPO-34 skeleton and effectively inhibits the decrease in activity; Na poisoning of Cu-SAPO-34 after SO2 treatment forms more stable sulfate species (e.g., Al2(SO4)3) after SO2 treatment, which seriously blocked the pores and reduced the active sites, and although it could be regenerated by heat treatment, the activity was still not as good as that of the Cu-SAPO-34 regenerated by simple S poisoning. The related mechanism is shown in Fig. 30 . 2.3 Cu-SSZ-39 2.3.1 Preparation Small-pore molecular sieve catalysts are active and selective, and in recent years, attention has gradually shifted to other novel small-pore molecular sieve catalysts (Cu-SSZ-39). Moliner et al. [97] first used hydroxide N,N-dimethyl-3,5-dimethylpiperidine in 2012 (Fig. 31 a) as a templating agent and Cu(CH3COO)2 as a copper source, Cu-SSZ-39 molecular sieves were synthesized by liquid phase ion exchange method with excellent activity and high temperature hydrothermal stability. Before the synthesis of Cu-SSZ-39, the synthesis of SSZ-39 molecular sieves was required. Scholars developed different organic structure-directing agents to synthesize SSZ-39 molecular sieves. Xu et al. [98] summarized the templating agents required for the synthesis of SSZ-39 molecular sieves, and the results are shown in Fig. 32 where a-h are cyclic quaternary amine molecules, with N,N-dimethyl-3,5-dimethylpiperidinium (Fig. 31a) and N,N-dimethyl-2,6-dimethylpiperidinium (Fig. 31j) are most commonly used (cheaper and better oriented). However, the use of cyclic quaternary amine molecules as templating agents is expensive and unfavorable for production. Therefore, in this case, scholars found that phosphorus-containing organic templates can also be used for SSZ-39 zeolite synthesis, such as tetraethylphosphonium (TEP, Fig. 31k). Schwalbe-Koda et al. [99] suggested that tris(dimethylamino)(methyl)phosphonium (Fig. 31l) could be used for the synthesis of SSZ-39 zeolites. However, such phosphorus-containing organic templates (TEP) may form monomers and condensed phosphate substances after high-temperature calcination in air, leading to clogging of the zeolite micropores[98]. Sonoda et al. [100] suggested that the decomposition of TEP cations in the pores of zeolites during heat treatment produces P-modified SSZ-39 zeolites, which significantly improves the thermal stability, but decreases the synthesized Cu-SSZ-39 catalytic activity. The conditions under which SSZ-39 zeolite was synthesized, had an important influence. Sonoda et al. [100] found that FAU is partially converted to MFI when seed crystals are not available. By adding seed crystals and fluoride source to the starting gel, highly crystalline high silica AEI zeolite was successfully synthesized with Si/Al ratio ranging from 13 to 20. None of the above synthesis methods can be done without Y-type zeolites (which must be de-aluminized), and they are all synthesis methods that convert the structure of the original zeolite. However, this method requires high silica USY zeolite with suitable physicochemical properties and complicated post-synthesis treatment. However, the complete conversion of USY zeolite to SSZ-39 zeolite takes a long time, approximately 7 days [97,100,101]. All these factors are unfavorable for industrial production, which is not what we would like to see. Although some scholars later replaced the transformed zeolite with ZSM-5 and β molecular sieves and successfully prepared SSZ-39 molecular sieves in the presence of DMPOH and under hydrothermal conditions[102]. However, the cost remains high. In this context, scholars developed a direct synthesis of SSZ-39 zeolite. Hu et al. [103] reported a rapid and direct route for the synthesis of SSZ-39 zeolite from colloidal silica and sodium aluminate under low OSDA consumption conditions (TMPOH/SiO2 = 0.09) and KOH containing molecular sieves, which perfectly solved the unfavorable factors mentioned above for the synthesis of Cu-SSZ-39, and the synthesized Cu-SSZ-39 has excellent hydrothermal stability and NH3-SCR activity. For the effect of Cu loading of Cu-SSZ-39, Fu et al. [104] found that high Cu loading was associated with more active species, good low-temperature catalytic activity, and high-temperature hydrothermal stability. Du et al. [105] found that the low-temperature NH3-SCR of Cu-SSZ-39 catalysts with a moderate Cu content (1.3 ∼ 2.0 wt.%) was treated with hydrothermal aging, and its low-temperature NH3-SCR performance was enhanced, but neither too low nor too high Cu content promoted it. Zhu et al. [106] concluded that NO2 could improve the conversion of Cu-SSZ-39 at low Cu loading. 2.3.2 Structure and active site As shown in Fig. 33 , the SSZ-39 molecular sieve is formed by interconnecting the D6R structural units to form a silica-aluminate microporous material with four-membered, six-membered, and eight-membered rings, and the stacking of hexagonal prismatic structural units between each other forms a pear-shaped supercage with 8MR orifices (3.8Å × 3.8Å) and a characteristic structure of the AEI, and each pear-shaped supercage consists of 36 T-atoms[107]. The SSZ-39 molecular sieve system contains three different T-sites, which are specific locations within the framework structure. These T-sites are the tetrahedral centers in the molecular sieve skeleton, and they play an important role in the structure. These T-sites can interact with adsorbed molecules and affect the catalytic performance and selectivity of the molecular sieve. By controlling and adjusting the chemical environment and properties of these T sites, the catalytic activity and selectivity of molecular sieves can be regulated and optimized. Unlike SSZ-13, SSZ-39 zeolite has an AEI topology. The SSZ-13 molecular sieves with rhombic zeolite (CHA) structure have the same D6R structural units, the difference lies in the way of connecting the D6R basic structural units, the SSZ-13 molecular sieves are arranged in parallel, whereas the D6R structural units are arranged at an angle in mirror-symmetric cross-distributed arrangement in the SSZ-39 molecular sieves (Fig. 32)[107]. Fu et al. [104] suggested that at low Cu loading, Cu exists in ZCuOH and Z2Cu forms, while samples with high Cu loading contain CuOx species. Shan et al. [107] hypothesized that the Cu-active species in Cu-SSZ-39 are ZCuOH near the 8MR and Z2Cu near the 6MR sites. Furthermore, at the same Cu loading, there were more Z2Cu species in fresh Cu-SSZ-39 than in Cu-SSZ-13. This also indicates in disguise that Cu-SSZ-39 is more resistant to hydrothermal aging than Cu-SSZ-13. In addition, Cu-SSZ-39 has less Al uncoordinated with copper species and possesses a more tortuous channel structure, resulting in better hydrothermal stability. ZCuOH and Z2Cu are considered the active species, and Du et al. [105] suggested that CuO x seems likely to be the active species as well and appears to be more active than active Cu2+. 2.3.3 Hydrothermal aging properties In the previous section, we discussed that Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst is widely studied and known for its excellent catalytic activity and temperature response window, but its high-temperature hydrothermal stability is less promising. Al-rich Cu-SSZ-39 (Si/Al < 8) not only exhibits excellent NH3-SCR performance, but also has excellent high-temperature hydrothermal stability, and has been shown to have more excellent NH3-SCR activity after hydrothermal aging at 850 °C [107]. Under the same hydrothermal aging conditions, Cu-SSZ-13 is more severely deactivated than Cu-SSZ-39[97]. The content of Cu active species is an important indicator of catalyst activity. Shan et al. [107] concluded that after hydrothermal aging Cu-SSZ-39 catalyst retained more active Cu2+ ions and formed less CuO x . Chen et al. [108] found that Cu-SSZ-39 showed a slight decrease in Lewis acid sites but a significant decrease in Brønsted sites after hydrothermal aging treatment. Albarracin-Caballero et al. [109] found that hydrothermal aging led to dealumination. Fu et al. [104] concluded that high temperature aluminum stripped from Cu-SSZ-39 after hydrothermal treatment interacts with CuO x to form Cu(AlO2)2 species, which increases with Cu content. Du et al. [105] found that after hydrothermal treatment some of the Cu2+ aggregates to form CuO x , and that the CuO x species facilitates the formation of nitrate species, which bypasses the rate-determining step of the Cu+ species migrating to activate O2 and NO, and increases the SCR activity of Cu-SSZ-39 (Fig. 33). 2.3.4 S poisoning The S poisoning mechanism of Cu-SSZ-39 is similar to that of Cu-SSZ-13. From Fig. 34 , it is easy to find that the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity of Cu-SSZ-39 was significantly reduced after S poisoning. Du et al. [110], after sulfidation of Cu-SSZ-39 in the presence of water at different temperatures (200 °C, 400 °C or 600 °C), found that sulfidation at 200 °C and 400 °C significantly reduced the low-temperature SCR activity, while sulfation at 600 °C had a lesser effect. Despite sulfidation, the structure of the samples remained relatively intact, maintaining the AEI structure with a slight decrease in specific surface area and pore volume. Sulfuric acid treatment at different temperatures affected the sulfate fraction on Cu-SSZ-39. At low temperatures (200 °C and 400 °C), H2SO4 and CuSO4 appeared in Cu-SSZ-39, whereas at high temperatures, H2SO4 disappeared and only CuSO4 was present. In addition, Al2(SO4)3 was found in all the samples treated with sulfide, but it seemed to have little effect on the catalyst performance. Based on the S poisoning mechanism of Cu-SSZ-13 and the above, we can briefly speculate the poisoning mechanism on Cu-SSZ-39: (i) the Cu active sites are reduced and transformed into CuSO4, which leads to pore blockage, resulting in the decrease of specific surface area and pore volume; (ii) the Brønsted acid sites are reduced and covered by H2SO4, which reduces the adsorption of NH3. The poisoned catalyst can be regenerated at high temperatures and the catalytic activity of the regenerated catalyst is less affected by temperature (Fig. 34), but only part of the activity can be recovered. This is because H2SO4 can decompose at high temperatures, so its poisoning effect is reversible, while the effect of CuSO4 is irreversible because it needs higher temperature to decompose. There are relatively few studies on the S poisoning of Cu-SSZ-39, and the above poisoning mechanism needs to be further developed. 2.3.5 P poisoning Chen et al. [108] found that phosphorus poisoning significantly affected the activity of Cu-SSZ-39 catalysts and aggravated with increasing P loading. The high-temperature catalytic activity of Cu-SSZ-39 was slightly increased at low phosphorus concentration (0.2 mmol/gcat.), while the low-temperature NH3-SCR performance was decreased. Phosphorus-poisoned Cu-SSZ-39 catalysts were present with orthophosphoric acid (H3PO4), low-cohesive polyphosphates (short-chain polyphosphates), monodentate/bidendate phosphates, aluminum phosphate (AlPO4), cohesive polyphosphates, and phosphorus oxide (P2O5). The content of all phosphorus species (P2O5, PO3 − and PO4 3−) on the catalyst surface tends to increase with increasing phosphorus loading. These P species can bind to the active Cu species or clog the pores, leading to a decrease in catalyst activity. In addition to the active site being affected, the Brønsted acid sites on Cu-SSZ-39 decreases dramatically after P poisoning. Therefore, there are similarities in the deactivation mechanism between Cu-SSZ-13 and Cu-SSZ-39 caused by phosphorus poisoning. The loss of active Cu2+ sites and the formation of copper phosphate species, as well as the reduction of acid sites, are responsible for the deactivation of the phosphorus-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst, which is also true for Cu-SSZ-39. P-poisoned Cu-SSZ-39, after hydrothermal aging treatment, showed a decrease in all phosphorus species, especially PO3 − content, but an increase in AlPO4 (Fig. 35 ). However, these AlPO4 substances stabilized the zeolite structure and prevented the collapse of the framework. Thus, hydrothermal aging treatment decomposed Cu-P species on P-poisoned Cu-SSZ-39, restored active Cu2+ ions, and generated CuO x species and inhibited their overproduction. Although Chen et al. conducted a detailed study of P poisoning and hydrothermal aging treatment on Cu-SSZ-39, the detailed poisoning mechanism for the poisoning of Cu sites on Cu-SSZ-39, as well as the effect on the NH3-SCR reaction cycle, still need to be further investigated. 2.3.6 Alkali and alkaline earth metal poisoning Cu-SSZ-39 can experience deactivation due to alkali or alkaline earth metal poisoning, which results in a decrease in the specific surface area, acid sites, active copper ions, and a substantial decrease in the catalytic performance of NH3-SCR[111]. Zhu et al. [111] attributed the main reason of the deactivation in alkali/alkaline earth metal-poisoned Cu-SSZ-39 to a substantial decrease in the acid sites and the transformation of the active Cu2+ ions into CuO x and CuAlO x . This mechanism is similar to that of Cu-SSZ-13 alkali/alkaline earth metal poisoning. Among alkali and alkaline earth metals, Na and K have a greater effect on the surface acidity of molecular sieves, while Ca and Mg have a greater effect on the structure of the molecular sieves. In addition, different alkali metals (K, Na) and alkaline earth metals (Ca, Mg), the degree of deactivation induced is different, and the corresponding order is K>Mg>Ca>Na (Fig. 36 ). This trend appears to differ slightly from that observed in Cu-CHA zeolites. In addition, high-temperature hydrothermal aging treatment after Cu-SSZ-39 alkali/alkaline-earth metal poisoning caused more severe deactivation, but their interactions have not been specifically elucidated. 2.4 Cu-SAPO-18 2.4.1 Preparation Cu-SAPO-18 is also one of the catalysts that have received much attention in recent years. Chen et al. [112] described the synthesis of SAPO-18 using N,N-diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA) as an organic structure-directing agent (OSDA). Ye et al. [113] reported for the first time in 2012 the synthesis of SAPO-18 molecular sieves using DIPEA as a templating agent and further synthesized by ion exchange of Cu-SAPO-18 molecular sieves, and the synthesized Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst had excellent SCR activity and hydrothermal stability. However, the use of DIPEA was expensive, and the single-template approach and small particle size posed challenges for industrial application and separation/recovery processes. In addition, the ion-exchange method, as mentioned earlier, is cumbersome as it requires steps such as ion exchange and calcination (which can lead to a decrease in the crystallinity of SAPOs and an uneven distribution of Cu2+ cations). Therefore, scholars have investigated the direct synthesis method, i.e., one-pot synthesis. Martínez-Franco et al. [114] directly prepared highly active and hydrothermally stable Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts for the first time by using the organometallic copper complexes, Cu(II) triethylenetetramine (Cu-TETA) and N,N-dimethyl-3,5-dimethylpiperidine, as the structural guiding agents. This approach yielded catalysts with high solid yield, a high number of isolated silica species in the zeolite framework, and a controllable number of cationic copper species outside the framework, resulting in excellent catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability. Turrina et al. [115] found that triethylenetetramine (TETA), N,N-bis(2-aminoethyl)-1,3-propanediamine (232) is more suitable for the synthesis of Cu-SAPO-18. However, this synthesis method produces a large amount of mother liquor, which will inevitably lead to a great waste if the mother liquor is treated as a waste liquid. Therefore, Guo et al. [116] synthesized Cu-SAPO-18 by one-pot method using mother liquor as raw material. This method is green and conducive to sustainable development. Moreover, the Cu-SAPO-18 synthesized using the mother liquor exhibited improved high-temperature SCR activity and hydrothermal stability compared to conventionally synthesized Cu-SAPO-18. However, an excessive amount of mother liquor could cause structural damage to the zeolite. Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts with a great number of acidic sites and active Cu2+ species have good NH3-SCR activity. Cu content and Si content also affect the catalytic performance of the catalysts by influencing the acidic sites and active Cu2+ species. For Cu-SAPO-18, the Cu content mainly activates the number of Cu sites, which in turn affects the activity of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst. Ming et al. [117] prepared Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts by wet impregnation and found that the number of active Cu2+ species and CuO x species increased with the increase of the Cu content, respectively, which in turn increased the catalytic activity, and the Cu content did not affect the structure of the catalyst, but the high temperature activity decreased in high Cu samples. Gao et al. [118] found the highest active Cu2+ content and the best Cu-SAPO-18 activity on samples with a Cu/Al mass ratio of 0.045. In addition, Si content also affects the content of acid sites and the distribution of active sites and the distribution of active sites in the catalyst. Chen et al. [119] synthesized SAPO-18 samples with different Si contents by hydrothermal method and found that Si replaced aluminum and phosphorus (the amount of substituted phosphorus was greater than the amount of substituted aluminum) and the number of Brønsted acid sites increased with the addition of Si in the structure. Ming et al. [117] also observed that the number of acid sites and active Cu2+ ions in Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts increased with increasing Si content, but reached a peak and decreased beyond a certain Si content level. And both high Si (much Si(0OAl) structure, which is easily destroyed during hydrothermal treatment) and low Si (severe loss of Cu2+ species due to hydrothermal treatment) are detrimental to the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-18. Chen et al. [119] also found that the number of acid sites and active Cu2+ ions first increased and then decreased with the increase of Si content. It was mentioned earlier that post-synthesis treatment can enhance improve the performance of catalysts. Zhu et al. [120] treated Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts with H2 reduction treatment, and their NO x conversion increased from 45% to 80% at 175 °C and from 80% to 100% at 200 °C, with a significant increase in low-temperature activity (Fig. 37 ). This is because, after H2 reduction treatment, Cu2+ on Cu-SAPO-18 is converted to Cu+ and the increase in Cu+/Cu2+ ratio improves the low temperature SCR activity. At low temperatures, Cu-SAPO-18 has higher activity than Cu-SAPO-34, but lower acid sites density and strength. However, the low-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 is extremely poor. To overcome these drawbacks, Zhang et al. [121] developed Cu-SAPO-18/34 co-generated molecular sieve catalysts with better NH3-SCR catalytic activity, hydrothermal stability and SO2 resistance (Fig. 38 ). Compared with Cu-SAPO-18 and Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, the Cu-SAPO-18/34 catalysts had a larger surface area, higher Si(nOAl) (n=1∼4) structure, which led to a greater number and strength of acidic sites, thus favoring the generation of more isolated copper ions (Cu2+ and Cu+) and inhibiting the formation of CuO x . 2.4.2 Structure and active site Indeed, Cu-SAPO-18 is an AEI-type zeolite, similar to Cu-SSZ-39. As shown in Fig. 39 , SAPO-18 shares the same layer arrangement as SAPO-34 but exhibits an AB stacking pattern, resulting in alternating D6R tilts. Structurally, SAPO-34 and SAPO-18 are similar; however, Cu-SAPO-18 has a lower density and intensity of acid sites compared to Cu-SAPO-34. For Brønsted acid sites, Chen et al. [122] on found that the number of Brønsted acid sites in SAPO-18 is significantly less than that of SAPO-34 which has a similar Si/(Si + A1 + P) ratio. Previously, we mentioned that in SAPO-34, Si atoms are formed by the substitution of Si for one P, whereas in SAPO-18 there are also substitution of one P and one Al by two Si, so the latter has relatively fewer acidic sites. There are many Cu species in Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts, including Cu2+, Cu+ and CuO x [124]. However, the dimer [Cu-O-Cu]2+, which is considered as the active species in Cu-SSZ-13, was not observed. Many scholars have found active Cu2+ ions to be the active site of the catalyst [114,124], CuO x species, on the other hand, can cause non-selective oxidation of ammonia and inhibit the SCR activity. The low-temperature SCR activity of the catalyst increases with the amount of Cu2+ ions[124]. Martínez-Franco et al. [114] suggested that the active Cu ions in Cu-SAPO-18 are mainly the Cu2+ outside the framework. Li et al. [124], by optimizing seven possible active sites, concluded that active Cu2+ is located in a pear-shaped cavity and tends to be close to the 6R face of Cu-SAPO-18. Turrina et al. [115] found that in SAPO-34, the Cu2+ cation is located in the CHA cage, whereas in SAPO-18, the Cu2+ cation is located in the center of the 6Rs of the D6R subunit of the AEI structure. As mentioned previously, the coordination structure of Si affects the acid properties and Cu distribution in Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts, as well as in Cu-SAPO-18. Martínez-Franco et al. [114] suggested that isolated Si species bring high hydrothermal stability and activity to these Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts, while Si islands are detrimental to the catalysts' activity and stability (Fig. 40 ). Chen et al. [119] found that the more Si(xOAl) (x=1∼3) structures in Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts, the more strong acid sites were produced. Ming et al. [117] pointed out that Si(0OAl) was easily destroyed during hydrothermal treatment. 2.4.3 Hydrothermal aging properties Cu-SAPO-18 has excellent low-temperature hydrothermal stability and high-temperature hydrothermal stability, while Cu-SAPO-34 has poor low-temperature hydrothermal stability. Low-temperature hydrothermal treatment has less impact on Cu-SAPO-18 samples, resulting in minimal structural disruption and preservation of the active components[118]. Similar to Cu-SAPO-34, the low-temperature catalytic activity of Cu-SAPO-18 increased after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment. As shown in Fig. 41 , Ma et al. [125] found that the NH3-SCR activity (<450 °C) of Cu-SAPO-38 increased after high-temperature aging treatment and continued to increase with the aging temperature. Gao et al. [118] found that after Cu-SAPO-18 is subjected to high-temperature aging treatment, CuO x within the catalyst reacts with protons to form more active Cu2+ ions, thus increasing the catalyst SCR reaction activity. However, the harsh aging at 900 °C leads to the collapse of the zeolite structure, which reduces the SCR reaction activity. Therefore, too high temperature does not improve the catalytic activity, but rather deactivates the catalyst. Pore diffusion limitation has a great influence on the activity of NH3-SCR reaction. Aging treatment can reduce the pore diffusion limit of catalyst. Turrina et al. [115] also found that the hydrothermal treatment at 900 °C resulted in loss of crystallinity and hence inactivity. Ming et al. [117] found that Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts with low acid site content suffered from a more severe loss of Cu2+ segregated states during hydrothermal treatment, resulting in poorer hydrothermal stability. Gao et al. [118] summarized the reasons for the deactivation of high-temperature hydrothermal aging: (i) the reduction of active Cu2+ species to Cu+ species accelerates the collapse of the zeolite structure; (ii) after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment, the hydrolysis of P-OH and Si-O(H)-Al (leading to the reduction of Lewis and Brønsted acid centers) as well as the formation of the backbone by Al as a ligand atom (Al(OP)4 or Al(OSi)(OP)3) are severely disrupted. For the changes in Cu species, Gao et al. [118] attributed the decrease in the number of active Cu2+ ions in D6R to the destruction of the zeolite structure and migration to 8MR, while the increase in the number of Cu+ ions was due to the transition of copper species: Cu2+ → CuO x → Cu2O. 2.4.4 S poisoning Cu-SAPO-18 after S poisoning showed a significant decrease in low-temperature activity and little change in high-temperature activity[126]. In addition, the more severe the low-temperature inactivation of Cu-SAPO-18 was with increasing SO2 concentration. Ming et al. [126] detected sulfite and sulfate species on the surface of Cu-SAPO-18 after exposing Cu-SAPO-18 to SO2 and O2 for 40 minutes. These sulfite and sulfate species caused microporous blockage, leading to a decrease in the specific surface area and microporous volume of Cu-SAPO-18. In addition, active Cu2+ ions located in the pear-shaped cavities of the AEI structure are more severely poisoned by SO2 than Cu2+ ions in D6R. Therefore, the decrease in acid sites and Cu active sites, along with the formation of sulfite and sulfate species, contribute to the inactivation of Cu-SAPO-18. As shown in Fig. 42 , SO2 poisoning inhibited the adsorption of NO, O2 and NH3 at the Cu2+ site, which reduced the Cu-NO x and Cu-NH3 intermediates, and apparently the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism was inhibited by SO2. The unstable sulfate on the catalyst surface can decompose at high temperatures, so the deactivated Cu-SAPO-18 can be regenerated at 550 °C. In general, the NO conversion of Cu-SAPO-18 with slight SO2 poisoning can be basically recovered, but for Cu-SAPO-18 with more severe SO2 poisoning, its SCR activity cannot be completely recovered after regeneration. 2.4.5 Alkali and alkaline earth metal poisoning Scholars have studied the toxic effects of alkali and alkaline earth metals on Cu-SAPO-18 [127,128]. Gao et al. [127] prepared a series of samples with different Ca contents by impregnation method, and found that the higher the doping amount of Ca, the worse the catalytic activity was. The mechanism of Ca2+ poisoning is as follows[127]: (i) Ca poisoning has little effect on the structure of Cu-SAPO-18 but the formation of CaO will block part of the micropores, reducing the specific surface area and microporous volume of the sample, further decreasing the accessibility and surface acidity of the active sites; (ii) the addition of Ca directly leads to a decrease in the number of active Cu2+ ions; (iii) Ca2+ will replace the H in Si-O(H)-Al or Si-O(Cu2+)-Al and Cu2+ to form Si-O-(Ca2+)-Al thereby reducing Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites, which may be an important reason for the decrease in catalytic activity. Ming et al. [128] investigated in detail the effect of K, Na, Ca and Mg on the intoxication of Cu-SAPO-18, and found that the corresponding order of deactivation was K > Na > Ca > Mg (Fig. 43 ). The reasons for the toxic deactivation of the catalysts by alkali or alkaline earth metals are all stated to be similar and are mainly related to the decrease in the acidic sites and the content of active Cu2+ species as well as the destruction of the zeolite framework. In addition, Cu2+ is converted to CuO x species and CuAl2O4-like species, leading to microporous plugging of Cu-SAPO-18, which further covers the acidic sites of the catalyst. Moreover, the effect of alkali or alkaline earth metals on the acidic sites was much greater than that on the active Cu2+ ions and zeolite frameworks. In addition, the catalytic mechanism of the samples was not changed by alkali or alkaline earth metal poisoning, but only reduced the reaction rate of the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction. Meng et al. [129] investigated the synergistic effect of K poisoning and hydrothermal aging on Cu-SAPO-18. They concluded that K poisoning deactivated Cu-SAPO-18 more severely after hydrothermal aging treatment. 2.5 Cu-SSZ-16 2.5.1 Preparation Cu-SSZ-16 has excellent NH3-SCR activity and resistance to hydrothermal aging, and is considered one of the few alternatives to Cu-SSZ-13. SSZ-16 is also a small-pore molecular sieve, Li et al. [130] synthesized SSZ-16 molecular sieves with AFX topology by a hydrothermal method using 1,4-diazabicyclo-[2.2.2]-octane-C4-diquinodibromide (DABCO) as an organic structure-directing agent. Subsequently, Cu-SSZ-16 catalysts were prepared using ion-exchange method and found to have better denitrification performance. Hrabanek et al. [131] used N,N'-bis-triethylpentanediyldiammonium cation ((C2H5)3N+(CH2)5N+(C2H5)3) as a structure-directing agent, synthesized SSZ-16 zeolite by static hydrothermal synthesis using different Si sources. Monomeric silica showed inefficient synthesis of SSZ-16 due to hydrolysis, while fumed silica and colloidal silica successfully produced SSZ-16. Fumed silica is cheaper and the synthesis of SSZ-16 is shorter but may form viscous hydrogels that are difficult to handle, and colloidal silica takes longer to synthesize but synthesizes zeolites with smaller particle sizes. In addition, the increase in hydrothermal temperature during synthesis favors nucleation. However, the above methods often take several days to synthesize SSZ-16 zeolite, which is not conducive to industrial production. The traditional synthesis method is carried out in a thermal reactor, but the thermal reactor will have the problem of thermal hysteresis, and the temperature is the key factor affecting the zeolite synthesis. Therefore, Chokkalingam et al. [132] reported an ultrafast synthesis technique using seed-assisted synthesis under a tubular reactor, which reduced the synthesis time of SSZ-16 to 2 h. Cu-SSZ-16 prepared by Cu ion exchange with the above synthesized SSZ-16 has a high degree of crystallinity and hydrothermal stability, and when aged hydrothermally at 800 °C it still possesses high catalytic activity after hydrothermal aging at 800 °C. In addition, compared with the conventional templating agent 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-4-aza-1-azoniabicyclo[2.2.2]octane dibromide (DABCO), N,N,N',N'-tetraethylbicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3:5,6-dipyrrolidinium (TEBOP) as a structure-directing agent for the synthesis of Cu-SSZ-16 synthesis exhibits higher crystallinity and hydrothermal stability. The catalytic activity of Cu-SSZ-16 was found by Chen et al. [133] to be enhanced with the increase of Cu loading while the high temperature activity was decreased and the temperature window was shifted to the low temperature region. In addition, high Cu loading was unfavorable for activity (the temperature window was too narrow) and selectivity. 2.5.2 Structure and active site Unlike Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SSZ-16 is a molecular sieve catalyst with AFX topology. The double six-membered ring (DR6) in the SSZ-13 zeolite was previously mentioned to be connected through the AABBCC sequence and formed a CHA cage. In contrast, the SSZ-16 zeolite framework consists of two types of cages: the gmelinite (gme) cage with BBCC sequences and the larger aft cage with AABBCCBB sequences, and the related structures are also shown in Fig. 44 . In addition, SSZ-16 has a smaller pore size of 3.6 Å × 3.4 Å compared to SSZ-13[134]. The structural similarity of AFX and CHA results in identical chemical and coordination states of the Cu-loaded material in Cu-SSZ-16 and Cu-SSZ-13[133].Wang et al. [135] speculated the position of the cations exchangeable in SSZ-16, with site I close to the center of the caged unit, site II close to the 8-MR window of the caged unit, and site III shifted from the 6-MR shifted to the caged unit, and site IV was near the center of the hexagonal prism (D6R unit) (Fig. 45 ). And the Cu active sites on Cu-SSZ-16 are Z2Cu and ZCuOH, and Fig. 47 reveals their locations in the SSZ-16 molecular sieve. Fickel et al. [136] suggested that Cu1 is located on the outer side of the six-membered ring, while Cu2 is located in the larger cage and each of them is connected to a different six-membered ring. 2.5.3 Hydrothermal aging properties Cu-SSZ-16 has relatively excellent high-temperature hydrothermal stability. Fickel et al. [137] found that the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity of Cu-SSZ-16 was almost unaffected and the high-temperature activity was slightly decreased after a 7-h treatment at 750 °C. Li et al. [130] found that the catalytic activity of Cu-SSZ-16 after hydrothermal aging at 650 °C and 750 °C was only slightly affected, but after hydrothermal aging at 850 °C, the catalyst performance was severely affected (Fig. 46 ). Li et al. [130] investigated in detail the effect of hydrothermal aging on the active components of the catalyst and the AFX skeleton. For the reason of inactivation of Cu-SSZ-16, Li et al. [130] attributed it to the collapse of the AFX backbone and the loss of Cu active species. The species of Al-OH-Si, terminal Si-OH and Lewis acid sites in Cu-SSZ-16 after hydrothermal aging were reduced and there was also the generation of CuO x and Cu(AlO2)2. Wang et al. [135] conducted hydrothermal aging experiments on Cu-SSZ-16, and found that the concentration of Cu2+ in the catalyst decreased after hydrothermal aging. In addition, it was mentioned earlier that Cu-SSZ-13 undergoes a transition from ZCuOH sites to Z2Cu sites and CuO x during hydrothermal aging, whereas this effect is suppressed in Cu-SSZ-16 in comparison. In summary, we can find that both Cu-SSZ-16 and Cu-SSZ-13 have relatively excellent hydrothermal stability (can withstand less severe high-temperature hydrothermal aging) and similar hydrothermal aging deactivation mechanisms (collapse of molecular sieve skeleton and transformation of Cu active species). 2.6 Cu-ZSM-5 2.6.1 Preparation Synthesis and modification of ZSM-5 molecular sieves are complex processes, involving techniques that utilize different templating agents, silicon sources, and aluminum sources. Still, the bedrock of these techniques is the reordering of silica-aluminum species. Among the many synthetic methods, the earliest Bibby et al. [138] used tetrapropylammonium hydroxide containing quaternary ammonium cation as the template agent, but the template agent is expensive, and the synthesis of industrial waste, which seriously affects the promotion of this method in the industry. Later, the synthesis method using ammonia as templating agent was found after research. After loading Cu species onto ZSM-5, scholars have found better denitrification activity and stability. Jamalzadeh et al. [139] found that the addition of copper ions improved the adsorption capacity of ZSM-5 and achieved high selectivity of the desired product for the Cu-ZSM5 catalyst at 300 °C. There are many methods for the synthesis of Cu-exchanged ZSM-5 zeolites, such as ion exchange (IE), impregnation (IM), ultrasound-enhanced impregnation (UIM), deposition precipitation (DP), and homogeneous deposition precipitation (HDP) with the use of urea, etc. Panahi et al. [140] investigated in detail the effect of different synthesis methods on the denitrification activity of Cu-ZSM-5. They reported the order of activity of Cu-ZSM-5 prepared by different methods as Cu-ZSM-5 (HDP) > Cu-ZSM-5 (UIM) > Cu-ZSM-5 (IM) > Cu-ZSM-5 (IE) > Cu-ZSM-5 (DP). In addition, they found that the adoption of HDP can make Cu-ZSM-5 contain more active Cu2+ ions and strong acidic sites. Moreover, the urea alkaline environment can also improve the particle size of ZSM-5, which increases the specific surface area and increases the activity. The synthesis of Cu-ZSM-5 from different Cu precursors affects its physicochemical properties and consequently its NH3-SCR performance. Song et al. [141] prepared Cu-ZSM-5 catalysts by initial impregnation method using copper nitrate, copper sulfate and copper chloride as Cu sources, respectively. Upon comparison, it was found that the Cu-ZSM-5 copper species prepared using copper nitrate as Cu source were highly dispersed with high surface acidity as well as small average particle size of CuO x , resulting in the best catalytic performance. In addition, the Cu content also had an effect on the catalytic activity, and Xue et al. [142] found that the catalytic activity of Cu-ZSM-5 increased and then decreased with the increase of Cu content. Differences in Al source also have an effect on the stability of ZSM-5 zeolite, Berggrund et al. [143] concluded that ZSM-5 zeolite synthesized with AlCl3 as the aluminum source and synthesized has better stability than that synthesized with Al(NO3)3. AlCl3 provides more paired aluminum while copper ions will be coordinated differently depending on the aluminum distribution in the zeolite, which will in turn affect the activity and stability. The Si/Al ratio will have an impact on the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Ding et al. [144] found that as the Si/Al ratio increases, the NH3 adsorption capacity increases and the catalytic performance of the catalysts is better. Jabłońska et al. [145] found that the Si/Al ratio in the zeolite skeleton of ZSM-5 affects the nature and distribution of copper species, which in turn affects their use as NH3-SCR catalysts in terms of activity and selectivity. In this case, the Si/Al ratio in the zeolite skeleton can be controlled by the zeolite preparation temperature, and the Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5 materials synthesized at higher temperatures is relatively low. Sultana et al. [146] found that Na+ co-cation improves the catalytic performance of Cu-ZSM-5, mainly by increasing the content of active Cu species. 2.6.2 Structure and active site The molecular sieves described in the previous section are all cage-type molecular sieves, while ZSM-5 is a straight-through-channel type molecular sieve. In addition, ZSM-5 is an MFI-type zeolite. Synthesized initially in 1972, the crystal structure of ZSM-5 molecular sieve is comprised of silicon(aluminum)-oxygen tetrahedra that are interconnected via oxygen bridges to form a five-membered silicon(aluminum)ring. The basic structural unit of the molecular sieve consists of eight five-membered silicon(aluminum)rings, and belongs to a kind of zeolite molecular sieve with a high-silicon three-dimensional cross-channel structure. In terms of pore structure, ZSM-5 is composed of two different channels; firstly, a straight pore channel with an elliptical cross-section measuring 0.54 nm x 0.56 nm, and secondly, a Z-shaped pore channel with an almost circular cross-section measuring 0.52 nm x 0.58 nm. These two channels intersect each other to form the orthorhombic crystal system of the ZSM-5 molecular sieve, which belongs to the Pnma space group. Its cell parameters are a = 20.1 Å, b = 19.7 Å, c = 13.1 Å, and the cell composition can be illustrated as NanAlnSi96-nO192·16H2O, where n fluctuates between 0-27, indicating the number of Al atoms, albeit ensuring the total number of SiAl atoms remains fixed at 96[147]. Cu species are the key species for the catalytic effect of this catalyst. Morpurgo[148] found that Cu species in the Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst prepared by ion-exchange existed mainly in two forms: active Cu2+ ions and dimers, and a small amount of CuO x . Scholars demonstrated the catalytic activity of both dispersed CuO x and active Cu2+ ions by their studies. Zdravkova et al. [149] have confirmed the presence of Cu+(H2O) by IR studies, and dimeric Cu is the active center of the catalyst for SCR reaction. As shown in Fig. 47 , for the cation exchange sites in ZSM-5, Bergeret et al. [150] found the highest number of cations exchanged at site I or site II/II' located on the surface of the 10-membered ring (MR) or 12-membered MR channel. Site III locates in the center of the half-shared 6-MR unit (bold), while site III' is coordinated to the mel unit of ZSM-5. The hierarchical structure of the zeolite can have a large impact on the performance of the catalyst. Peng et al. [151] employed a bifunctional template and a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method to successfully prepare Cu-ZSM-5 molecular sieves with hierarchical pore structures (mesoporous and microporous), which showed better catalytic performance and SO2 resistance (in the low and intermediate temperature ranges) compared to the common molecular sieves with only microporous structures. They[151] concluded that the ordered mesoporous structure facilitates mass transfer with a large specific surface area, and that the Cu species have more redox capacity, surface acidity, and NO adsorption capacity, and more bidentate nitrate activity of the reaction process species. 2.6.3 Hydrothermal aging properties The flue gas in the real working environment is complex and the presence of water vapor is unavoidable, which seriously affects the NO removal. Some scholars have also made relevant studies on this phenomenon. For instance, Kharas et al. [152] discovered that the introduction of 10 % H2O rapidly deactivated the Cu-ZSM-5 at temperatures of 600 °C and 800 °C. This further underscores the sensitivity of the catalyst's performance to specific environmental factors. Landi et al. [153] who found that there was a competition between H2O and NO through low temperature adsorption experiments, which led to a decrease in the activity of the catalyst. Wang et al. [154] also found that the competitive adsorption between NO and H2O inhibited the uptake of NO on [Cu-O-Cu]2+ during the reaction and the reaction rate constant k1 increased with increasing temperature. In their study, they used the ion-exchange method to prepare Cu-ZSM-5 catalysts and extensively investigated the impacts of water vapor on the catalyst's performance. They found that the activity of the Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst drastically reduced with the increase of water vapor content, affecting NO conversion rate. In fact, they discovered that water vapor could irreversibly damage the catalyst. The effect of water vapor on the catalyst is fatal, not only in the backbone structure of the catalyst, but also on the catalyst's active species and other aspects. Firstly, for the active species (Cu) of the catalyst there is also a great influence. Zdravkova et al. [149] concluded that water vapor has a great influence on copper dimer. In addition, Wang et al. [154] found that copper ions in the active site were converted to inactive CuO x , and the formation of the reaction byproduct ZCuOH and the destruction of the catalyst skeleton reduced the dimer content. The diameter of CuO x was larger than that of copper ions, which led to growth, fracture, agglomeration of the grains of the catalyst. The results of crystal surface size calculations and grain morphology completely confirm the change process. Secondly for the structure of the catalyst, the ZSM-5 carrier can be severely damaged. Wang et al. [154] found that after water vapor treatment, the catalyst skeleton structure was destroyed and aluminum ions flowed out with the water vapor. The dealumination of the catalyst skeleton led to a decrease in micropores and an increase in mesopores. 2.6.4 P poisoning Phosphorus poisoning had a greater effect on the structure of Cu-ZSM-5 compared to Cu-SSZ-13. The structure of Cu-SSZ-13 remained basically unchanged after phosphorus poisoning, while the crystallinity of Cu-ZSM-5 samples decreased significantly. Wang et al. [155] conducted studies which indicated that the activity of Cu-ZSM-5 samples exhibited a dramatic reduction at low temperatures due to P poisoning, applied through the impregnation method. However, they observed that the activity of the samples remained relatively stable at high temperatures, despite the poisonous effects of phosphorus. The reason may be that phosphorus eroded the surface of the zeolite causing defects that led to localized swelling and cracking, which in turn led to the clogging of the zeolite pores of Cu-ZSM-5, affecting the free movement of ammonia-solvated copper ions under low-temperature conditions. This result reduces the rate of (NH3)2Cu2+-O2-Cu2+(NH3)2 formation, which is a key step for O2 activation. Whereas only one Cu2+ is required at high temperatures, which explains why the high temperature activity was not affected. In addition, the main P species generated in the P-poisoned samples were P2O5, PO3 − and PO4 3−. PO3 −/PO4 3− dominated in Cu-SSZ-13, while the opposite was true for Cu-ZSM-5. A possible reason is that the large pore size of MFI leads to a smaller spatial site resistance for large P2O5 species. P2O5 enhances the redox capacity of Cu ions, which improves the low-temperature activity of NH3-SCR, whereas PO3 −/PO4 3− is significantly toxic to Cu ions, leading to the low-temperature inactivation of Cu ions. 2.6.5 Alkali metal and alkaline earth poisoning Cu-ZSM-5 undergoes K poisoning, its NH3-SCR catalytic activity decreases and the deactivation becomes more pronounced with increasing K content (Fig. 48 )[156], as do effects such as Ca poisoning[142]. Xue et al. [156] found that the reduced CuO x content on the K-poisoned Cu-ZSM-5 catalysts decreased the reducibility and the adsorption of NH3 and NO x , which inhibited the formation of active bridged nitrate but promoted the formation of inactive bidentate nitrate. In addition, they[142] investigated the effect of Ca poisoning and found that Ca loading leads to a decrease in the specific surface area and a reduction in the number of acid sites of the Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst, and that the interaction of CaO with CuO x inhibits the reducibility of CuO x . The reduction of CuO x and Cu2+ ion content on the catalyst surface is responsible for the deactivation of Cu-ZSM-5 after Ca poisoning. 3 Fe-based molecular sieve catalysts 3.1 Fe-SSZ-13 3.1.1 Preparation All of the previously mentioned catalysts can be prepared using liquid-phase ion exchange, but liquid ion exchange of Fe ions in zeolites is more difficult, with the larger diameter of the Fe[H2O]6 3+ complex preventing the ions from entering the zeolite pores. In order to successfully conduct a liquid ion exchange of Fe in small and medium pore-sized zeolites, it is crucial to use Fe2+ precursors. Furthermore, the liquid must also be devoid of dissolved oxygen. This can be achieved through techniques such as degassing and initiating a flow of N2. These steps are essential to ensure the effectiveness of the exchange process. Some synthetic methods propose the addition of ascorbic acid as a deoxidizer to prevent the conversion of Fe2+ to Fe3+. Even with these precautions, producing iron zeolites with precisely controlled metal loading is problematic. Solid-state ion exchange (SSIE), on the other hand, is a simple and efficient method for synthesizing small-pore zeolite catalysts with different out-of-framework iron ion exchange. It allows the degree of ion exchange to be controlled to produce the active sites required for a particular catalytic reaction. The introduction of iron ions into SSZ-13 small pore molecular sieves, SSIE technique is a better alternative to the commonly used liquid ion exchange. Martinovic et al. [157] used FeCl2·4H2O as a precursor and NH3-SSZ-13 as a parent molecular sieve, after sufficient milling, under He gas flow and held at 550 °C for 30 min to obtain SSIE powder, and finally Fe-SSZ-13 catalyst was obtained by calcination at 650 °C. During the SSIE process, FeCl2 salt reacted with NH4 + ions at the zeolite exchange sites to form Fe-SSZ-13 and NH4Cl (Fig. 49 ). It was found that highly dispersed and non-homogeneous Fe sites were formed in the zeolite and their type depended on the distribution of Al in the zeolite. In addition, the exchange process of Fe ions in the zeolite framework is sequential, with Fe ions preferentially forming iron dimers (-Fe-O-Fe-) on 6MR and 8MR containing at least two Al-exchange sites at the beginning of the exchange, and once these sites are fully saturated, the Fe ions are exchanged as isolated cations. When the catalysts were synthesized without heating under an inert He flow but directly calcined in air, the NO x conversion was low, probably due to the inhibition of the SSIE process and the ion exchange of iron to form a stable FeOCl, and there was a severe decrease in the Fe loading and a decrease in the catalytic activity when the parent molecular sieve was replaced with H-SSZ-13 (Fig. 50 )[157]. Thus, SSIE exchange of iron can only occur when using stable iron ion salts that do not produce decomposition products such as oxides, using the NH4 form of zeolite, and only when heated in an O2 free atmosphere. However, the maximum Fe/Al ratio that can be obtained for catalysts prepared by this method is 0.5. The synthesis conditions also have an impact on the performance of the catalyst obtained (Fig. 50). The Fe-SSZ-13 prepared by impregnation method has a higher degree of Fe exchange, but is more prone to produce Fe2O3, while SSIE is less prone to produce Fe2O3, which favors NOx reduction, resulting in a lower activity for the former than for the latter[157]. The Fe/Al ratio also has an effect on the activity of the catalysts, and Martinovic et al. [157] synthesized Fe-SSZ-13 with different Fe loading levels using SSIE. It was found that the relative reducibility of Fe decreased with increasing Fe content. This is because with the increase in the degree of ion exchange, the proportion of stable isolated Fe3+ species and FeO x oligomers, which are not easily reducible in the temperature range studied, increased. Cheng et al. [158] also found that with the increase in Fe loading more Fe2O3 species and isolated Fe3+ were formed. Liu et al. [159] synthesized the relevant catalysts by a one-pot hydrothermal method and investigated the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of the catalysts calcined at different temperatures. It was shown that the calcination temperature had a great influence on the acidity, Fe species distribution and catalytic performance of Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts. The low-temperature activity (<425 °C) of Fe-SSZ-13 decreased with increasing calcination temperature, while its high-temperature activity increased somewhat. This is due to the fact that more isolated Fe3+ ions are retained within the catalyst at low calcination temperatures, and these ions can serve as Lewis acid sites and active sites at low reaction temperatures. Meanwhile, the stronger surface acidity helps to alleviate the inhibition of NH3 at low temperatures, resulting in good low-temperature activity. On the other hand, the high calcination temperature leads to slight aggregation of isolated Fe3+ to form dimeric/oligomeric Fe clusters, resulting in superior high temperature activity. 3.1.2 Structure and active site Similar to Cu-SSZ-13, both have the CHA structure, only the active elements are different. The catalyst has two key active centers, an isolated [Fe(OH)2]+ and a dimer [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ [160](Fig. 51 ), both located at the cationic position of charge equilibrium. This was also experimentally verified by Gao et al. [161], who using Mössbauer and FTIR spectroscopies, found that in hydrated fresh samples the possible monomer and dimerized iron ions were identified as [Fe(OH)2]+ and [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+. As can be seen in the Fig. 51, the isolated [Fe(OH)2] + site is the main low-temperature (< 300 °C) active center of standard SCR, while the [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ site is responsible for the high-temperature (≥ 300 °C) SCR activity and side-reactions, in particular the parasitic NH3 oxidation. The catalyst also contains a few sites, i.e., isolated Fe2+ sites and iron oxide clusters and particles. Isolated Fe2+ is also one of the key catalytic centers of SCR. The iron oxide clusters and particles can be considered as high temperature SCR active phases. However, since these are few sites and they catalyze the oxidation of NH3 by O2 at temperatures above 300 °C, they are not key contributors to the Fe-SSZ-13 SCR catalysts. Cheng et al. [158] found six subbands between 200-800 nm by UV-vis spectra, and the bands located between 200 and 300 nm are tetrahedrally coordinated (λ<250 nm) or octahedrally (250 nm < λ < 300 nm) coordinated isolated Fe3+ ions, and these isolated Fe3+ may appear as [Fe(OH)2]+ in hydrated samples. Two subbands in the 300∼400 nm region are associated with FeO x species. The lower wavelength band corresponds to the binuclear [HO-Fe-O-Fe-H]2+ species, while the other band is considered to belong to the multinuclear FeO x species (with a higher number of nuclei). The band above 400 nm is the Fe2O3 particles dispersed on the outer surface of the zeolite. This suggests that isolated Fe3+ ions and oligomeric FeO x species are the dominant Fe species in all samples. Overall[159], the main active Fe species as well as the acidic sites contribute differently to the low/high temperature activity. It can be concluded that isolated Fe3+ ions and oligomeric Fe clusters are active sites for low/high SCR reaction temperatures, respectively. Zeolite acidity plays a more important role in the low-temperature SCR reaction catalyzed by Fe-SSZ-13(Fig. 52 ). Zhang et al. [160] found Fe to be most energetically favorable at the 6MR site through DFT studies; however, with the addition of adsorbent, 8MR will become more favorable. For Fe2+ cations, the most stable configuration occurs in 8MR, where NO is co-adsorbed onto Fe with OH ligand. For Fe3+ cations, the lowest energy conformation occurs when NO is adsorbed directly onto Fe within 8MR without interacting with the OH ligand. The presence of hydroxyl groups seems to be important for Fe-SSZ-13, with O binding much more strongly to the Fe cation than to the Cu cation. 3.1.3 Hydrothermal aging properties Hydrothermal aging leads to catalyst dealumination and transformation of various iron sites. The latter include the transformation of free Fe2+ ions into dimerized Fe(III) species, the aggregation of isolated Fe ions into iron oxide clusters, and the incorporation of Al into iron oxide species. These changes have complex effects on standard SCR and NO/NH3 oxidation reactions. Briefly, mild aging improves the performance of SCR-capable catalysts, whereas severe aging at 800 °C decreases the performance of SCR-capable catalysts. Gao et al. [162], after severe HTA treatment of fresh Fe-SSZ-13 at 800 °C for 16 h, found that most of the Fe-containing groups within the catalysts were transformed into FeAlO x and FeO x clusters under the condition of 10 % water presence. species, however, the CHA structure of the catalyst and part of the extra framework of Fe ions were still present. This observation highlighted the robustness of Fe-SSZ-13 in maintaining high temperature SCR activity and selectivity post hydrothermal aging. Kovarik et al. [163] also found that during hydrothermal aging, the Fe-SSZ-13 catalyst undergoes dealumination and iron ion clustering. Among them, free Fe2+ ions were abundantly present in fresh samples and converted to [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ dimers during hydrothermal aging, and [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ dimers remained highly stable; even in HTA-800 samples, their content did not decrease. Iron oxide clusters of 1-2 nm in size are also formed during hydrothermal aging. These are distributed either inside individual SSZ-13 particles, probably in secondary pores created during aging, or on the outer surface of the zeolite. The isolated Al strongly interacts with Fe sites through the following mechanisms: some of the Al migrates out of the SSZ-13 particles before aging and binds to the pre-existing Fe-oxide particles; some migrates into the Fe-oxide clusters produced during aging; and the rest interacts with the [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ dimer alone through acid-base interactions. These interactions rendered the isolated Al NMR invisible. In terms of catalytic properties, mild hydrothermal aging at 600 and 700 °C reduces the inactive free Fe2+, thus improving the SCR performance. Severe aging at 800 °C leads to strong inhibition of various Fe sites by Al, which deteriorates the SCR performance. The oxidizing activity of NO and NH3 can also be attributed to Fe ion clustering and Al poisoning. 3.1.4 S poisoning For Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts containing one Al (1Al site) or two Al (2Al site) in 6MRs (6-membered rings) or 8MRs (8-membered rings), Mesilov et al. [164] investigated the effect of S poisoning on Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts and made a side-by-side comparison of the differences between Fe-SSZ-13 and Cu-SSZ-13. During low-temperature poisoning, the absence of ammonia in the gas mixture leads to the formation of ferrous sulfate on the 2Al site of Fe-SSZ-13, whereas the formation of ammonia sulfate is favored under SCR conditions. On the other hand, only ammonia-free iron sulfate can be formed on the 1Al site of Fe-SSZ-13, regardless of the presence or absence of ammonia. In contrast, both bisulfate and sulfate species can be formed at the Cu sites of Cu-SSZ-13, regardless of the presence or absence of ammonia, as well as during low and high temperature poisoning. The study found that sulfur-containing ligands desorb from Fe species at significantly higher temperatures in the 1Al system compared to the 2Al system, suggesting that Fe in the 2Al site is more readily regenerated after poisoning, while Fe in the 1Al site requires higher temperatures for regeneration. Ammonium sulfate in the 2Al system of Fe-SSZ-13 is the most stable at low temperatures (0∼500 K), and the 2Al site in Fe-SSZ-13 can be regenerated at 600 K, whereas desulfurization of the 1Al site needs to be carried out at 1100 K. In contrast to the Cu sites of Cu-SSZ-13, which readily form ammonium sulfate, the 1Al sites of Fe-SSZ-13 can only form ammonia-free iron sulfate at practical ammonia concentrations. The temperature for complete desorption of sulfur is expected to be higher for the 2Al sites of Cu-SSZ-13 compared to Fe-SSZ-13, and the temperature required to regenerate Fe species from the 1Al sites of Fe-SSZ-13 is higher than the temperature required to regenerate Cu species from the 1Al sites of Cu-SSZ-13. 3.2 Fe-ZSM-5 3.2.1 Preparation The increase of Fe loading in Fe-ZSM-5 not only increased the number of active Fe sites, but also changed the nature of Fe species [165].Wang et al. [165] prepared Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with different Fe contents by wet initial impregnation method, and found that the relative amount and the true content of the active Fe species on Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts play a significant role in their low-temperature catalytic activity. The low-temperature catalytic activity of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with Fe loadings of 1.0 wt % and 3.0 wt % were both higher, but the latter had lower high-temperature activity. This is due to the high relative content of isolated active Fe species in the low Fe-loaded Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts and the inherently high Fe content in the high Fe-loaded Fe-ZSM-5. However, the high number of oligomeric Fe and FeO x species in the high Fe-loaded Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts, their weakened high-temperature acidic sites, and the enhanced NH3 oxidation are the causes of the reduced high-temperature activity. Both too high and too low Fe/Al are detrimental to the catalytic performance of Fe-ZSM-5, and Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with appropriate Fe/Al ratio have the most obvious "SCR window" [165,166] (Fig. 53 ). Qi et al. [167] investigated the effect of Si/Al ratio on the performance of catalysts, and the NH3-SCR activities of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts prepared from zeolites with different Si/Al ratios were different. The results showed that the Si/Al ratio had a large effect on the NO conversion of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts in the range of 200∼550 °C, and in general, the activity of Fe-ZSM-5 with a lower Si/Al ratio was higher. This is the fact that the ZSM-5 molecular sieves with lower Si/Al ratios have higher BrØnsted acidity, which facilitates the adsorption of NH3. Different Fe salts also have an impact on the activity of the catalysts. Among FeSO4, FeCl2, FeCl3 and Fe(NO3)3, Qi et al. [167] found that the catalyst prepared from FeCl2 had the highest catalytic activity. And the order of catalytic activity is as follows: Fe/ZSM-5(FeCl2) > Fe/ZSM-5(FeCl3) > Fe/ZSM-5(FeSO4) > Fe/ZSM-5(Fe(NO3)3) Lai et al. [168] prepared Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts by ion-exchange method and found that the atmosphere during ion-exchange and roasting significantly affected the cation-exchange capacity and the nature of Fe species in the catalysts. The air atmosphere favored the Fe ion exchange capacity of ZSM-5 zeolite. Isolated Fe3+ sites dominated the Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts prepared under N2 atmosphere, whereas small oligomeric FeO x clusters and FeO x nanoparticles were more prevalent in air, resulting in higher SCR activity and wide temperature window. In addition, the Fe-ZSM-5 (N2) catalyst has more Brønsted acid sites, which can adsorb more NH3 species and thus improve its SCR activity. Post-synthesis methods such as wet impregnation[165], solid- or liquid-phase ion exchange[168], and chemical vapor deposition[169] can introduce extra-skeletal Fe species into the parent ZSM-5 zeolite. The Fe species distribution in Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by these methods varies widely, resulting in differences in SCR activity[168]. Shi et al. [170] prepared a series of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts by liquid ion exchange, incipient wet impregnation and solid state ion exchange. It was found that Fe-ZSM-5 prepared using the solid-state ion exchange method contained fewer isolated Fe3+ species and more large-sized Fe2O3 particles, and performed well at high temperatures but poorly at low temperatures. In contrast, Fe-ZSM-5 with high Fe loading and more isolated Fe3+ sites can be obtained using the initial impregnation method approach, but the very high Fe loading may negatively affect the SCR activity. Agglomeration of iron substances occurs at higher calcination temperatures, changing the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of the catalysts. Yu et al. [171] prepared and calcined Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts at different temperatures using the solution ion exchange method, and found that the NO conversion rate increased at higher calcination temperatures, and the SCR activity of the Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts was significantly increased. This is because the high temperature may lead to the conversion of inactive free Fe2+ to active Fe3+, retaining sufficient Lewis acid sites for NO adsorption for reaction with NH3 species, thus increasing the SCR activity of the catalyst. However, the coexistence of various extra-framework Fe species, such as isolated Fe ions, oligomerized clusters and Fe2O3 nanoparticles, is usually observed in Fe-ZSM-5 prepared by synthetic methods. While the catalytic effect of Fe2O3 on the reaction can be neglected, in order to construct highly dispersed out-of-framework Fe species, i.e., isolated Fe ions and oligomeric FeO x clusters, Yuan et al. [172] successfully developed a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis of Fe-ZSM-5 molecular sieves using the Fe complex EDTA-FeNa as the Fe source and the structure-directing agent. This method simplifies the synthesis process and leads to samples with higher activity in NH3-SCR. The prepared Fe-ZSM-5 molecular sieves are catalysts containing both suitable acidic centers and highly dispersed exoskeletal Fe species. In order to improve the hydrophobicity of Fe-ZSM-5 in NH3-SCR, Du et al. [173] prepared core-shell zeolites with Fe-ZSM-5 core and silicalite-1 shell by secondary hydrothermal crystallization. Due to the alkaline conditions during the secondary hydrothermal crystallization process, small amounts of Fe3+ and Al3+ were removed from the skeleton of Fe-ZSM-5 core and participated in the formation of the silicalite-1 shell. Silicalite-1 can adsorb NO x , and Fe species distributed in the silicalite-1 shell layer may act as new active centers also enhancing the adsorption capacity. Therefore, the NH3-SCR activity of Fe-ZSM-5 was significantly increased after a tiny silicalite-1 shell layer was encapsulated on its surface. Shi et al. [174] found that Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts prepared from H-ZSM-5 and Na-ZSM-5 exhibited different activity, hydrothermal stability and SO2 resistance due to having different acidity and Fe fraction distribution. Fe-ZSM-13(H) contained a higher relative concentration of isolated Fe3+ substances, while Fe-ZSM-13(Na) contained more oligomeric FeO x clusters and Fe2O3 particles. Thus, the zeolite structure of Fe-ZSM-13(Na) is more stable than that of Fe-ZSM-13(H) during hydrothermal aging. Fe-ZSM-5(H) exhibited higher SCR activity than Fe-ZSM-5(Na) both when fresh and after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C in 5 % H2O /air. The effects of water and SO2 on the activity of both catalysts were similar, with activity decreasing at low temperatures and increasing at high temperatures. The SO2 sum was found to be reversible for both Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts, but the activity of Fe-ZSM-13(Na) recovered better. 3.2.2 Structure and active site The SCR activity of iron-based zeolites is mainly dependent on the Fe species, with little effect of acidity[171]. Three types of iron are present in Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts, namely isolated Fe3+ sites, small oligomeric FeO x clusters and FeO x nanoparticles [168,170,173]. Even at temperatures less than 500 °C, the isolated Fe3+ sites are more active than the dimer [OH-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ in SCR and are the main site of the reaction. The Lewis acid sites on Fe-ZSM-5 is important for the low-temperature SCR reaction, whereas the Brønsted acid sites are less significant. The structure of the catalyst is crucial in relation to the performance of the catalyst. For Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts, previous studies have developed a variety of catalysts with unique morphology and structure. Feng et al. [175] investigated the effect of ZSM-5 morphology and size on SCR activity, and found that ZSM-5 zeolite with cauliflower-like morphology facilitated the distribution of active Fe3+, which in turn improved the catalytic activity. Shi et al. [176] prepared Fe-ZSM-5/WM by ion-exchange method using a mixture of 50 % deionized water and 50 % anhydrous methanol. Unlike the filamentous Fe species prepared using 100 % anhydrous methanol or the abundant Fe clusters prepared using 100 % deionized water, the catalysts prepared by this method were rich in small particles, with a better dispersion of Fe species within the zeolite, a proper ratio of Fe2+/Fe3+, enhanced oxidation properties, and a surface adsorption of oxygen species on the surface. As a result, the catalysts have better catalytic performance and resistance. In addition, the core-shell structure has recently attracted much attention. Zhang et al. [177] have taken advantage of the sequential reaction to develop Fe-ZSM-5@Ce/mesoporous-silica, which exhibits higher NO x conversion and N2 selectivity. This was attributed to the fact that NO was first oxidized to NO2 when passing through the Ce-loaded mesoporous silica shells, increasing the ratio of fast SCR reaction. Chen et al. [178] had a similar effect with the Fe-ZSM-5@CeO2 catalysts prepared by dopamine polymerization, which exhibited higher activity by creating a fast SCR environment through the CeO2 oxide layer (Fig. 54 ). The SCR activity of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts is primarily determined by the presence of specific Fe species, while the catalyst's acidity has minimal impact. The catalyst's structure, including morphology, particle size, and core-shell configuration, plays a crucial role in determining its catalytic performance. Various strategies have been explored to optimize the distribution and characteristics of Fe species within the catalyst, leading to improved catalytic activity and durability. 3.2.3 Hydrothermal aging properties After hydrothermal aging treatment of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts, the low-temperature activity of NH3-SCR decreased significantly while the high-temperature activity increased [170,179], and the surface area of the catalysts decreased slightly while the pore volume remained almost unchanged[170]. Shi et al. [180] prepared Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts by solid-state ion-exchange method and in the presence of 10 % H2O at hydrothermal deactivation at 800 °C. It was found that in the fast SCR reaction, the NO x conversion on the aged Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst increased significantly compared to that in the standard SCR reaction, but it was still lower than that of the fresh catalyst, and it had a substantially higher N2O production rate (Fig. 55 ). Shi et al. [170] observed that the aging of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts led to a decrease in the relative concentration of isolated Fe3+ species and an increase in the concentration of oligomeric FeO x clusters and Fe2O3 particles. They also noted a significant decrease in the Brønsted acidity of the catalysts. The ageing deactivation of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts was attributed to the change in the distribution of Fe species in the catalysts. Yu et al. [171] found that the hydrothermal aging process resulted in the dealumination of the catalysts, leading to the generation of H2O. The presence of H2O inhibited the conversion of Fe2+ to Fe3+ and the destruction of Brønsted acid centers, resulting in a decrease in SCR activity at high temperatures. Brandenberger et al. [179] summarized three causes of catalyst aging deactivation, as shown in Fig. 56 : (i) hydrolysis of Al-OH-Si sites with rapid dealumination, (ii) decomposition of dimeric iron, and (iii) slow migration of isolated iron ions followed by dealumination of these Al sites. From this, it is easy to find that the deactivation of Fe-ZSM-5 by hydrothermal aging is due to the destruction of the zeolite structure as well as the migration of reactive Fe and the formation of FeO x clusters, and the latter is the main reason. In addition, Fe-ZSM-5 remains active after hydrothermal aging because (iii) this process retains some isolated Fe ions. In summary, the aging of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts involves changes in the distribution of Fe species, dealumination of the catalysts, and the formation of FeO x clusters. These factors contribute to catalyst deactivation, and the formation of FeO x clusters is particularly influential. However, Fe-ZSM-5 still exhibits some activity after aging due to the presence of isolated Fe ions. 3.2.4 S poisoning The SO2 tolerance of Fe-ZSM-5 is higher than that of Cu-ZSM-5[167]. Feng et al. [181] conducted aging tests on Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts in an environment containing 500 ppm SO2 and 10 % H2O. They found that the catalysts maintained their catalytic performance at 400∼550 °C. Fig. 57 shows the results of SCR activity of fresh and SO2 treated Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts. It is evident that the NO conversion of Fe-ZSM-5 decreased significantly at lower temperatures after pretreatment at 700 °C with 10 % H2O and 500 ppm SO2 for 24 h. The NO conversion between fresh and SO2-treated Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts was almost the same at temperatures higher than 400 °C. The catalytic performance of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts treated with water alone was found to be very good, and the results were basically the same for Fe-ZSM-5 treated with water alone. Obviously, the effect of SO2 was almost negligible. Shi et al. [174] introduced 100 ppm SO2 into the flue gas to simulate diesel exhaust and conducted catalytic reactions using Fe-ZSM-5. They observed that the NO x conversion decreased at low temperatures (below 350 °C) and slightly increased at high temperatures (> 350 °C) in the presence of SO2. When water is added to the gas stream, the NO x conversion of the catalyst decreases sharply. This can also prove that SO2 has little effect on the catalyst. In addition, the SO2-poisoned Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst is reversible and can be regenerated by heating. Shi et al. [174] tested the activity of the poisoned catalyst by heating it at 550 °C for 30 min and found that the NO x conversion of the poisoned samples was partially recovered after heat treatment. 3.3 Fe-Beta 3.3.1 Preparation The Fe-Beta catalysts have demonstrated superior activity in the SCR compared to Fe-ZSM-5[182]. Some conventional methods, such as ion exchange and hydrothermal synthesis, have been widely applied to prepare zeolite catalysts. The content of active species in the catalyst has an important influence on the performance of the catalyst. For a specific mass of iron salt precursor, the concentration of the iron salt solution during ion exchange affects the degree of ion exchange and thus the SCR activity of the prepared Fe-Beta catalysts. Xia et al. [183] took advantage of this property by employing the same concentration of the iron salt solution to prepare three Fe-Beta catalysts with solid-liquid ratios of 1/20, 1/50, and 1/100, where the Fe contents were 2.6, 6.3 and 9 wt %, respectively. Although the Fe-Beta catalysts with different Fe loadings did not have significant differences in specific surface area, pore size, and valence of Fe, the Fe-Beta catalyst with 6.3 wt % Fe loading had a great number of isolated Fe3+ active sites, and thus possessed good NH3-SCR activity and selectivity. Zhu et al. [184] found that, at low temperatures (< 200 °C), the NO conversion significantly increased with increasing Fe loading, while at high temperatures (> 450 °C), the NO conversion decreased with increasing Fe loading. This was attributed to the decrease in the relative proportion of isolated Fe3+ and the increase in the relative proportion of agglomerated and massive FeO x with increasing Fe content. Zhu et al. [185] found that graded Fe-Beta obtained by hydrothermal synthesis has higher low temperature NH3-SCR activity than Fe-Beta prepared conventionally using ion exchange (Fig. 58 ). The differences were compared in terms of pore structure, acidity, and active Fe species. BET and TEM results confirmed that mesopore/macropores were introduced into the Beta zeolite. UV-vis DRS, EPR, and H2-TPR results showed that there were no significant differences in the Fe species between the catalysts prepared by the two methods. Both catalysts contained isolated Fe3+ species, oligomers, and Fe2O3. However, the hierarchically structured Fe-Beta catalysts with highly dispersed Fe active species. The presence of a hierarchical structure in the graded Fe-Beta catalysts introduced more defects and provided additional ion exchange sites for Fe species. This unique feature contributed to the highly dispersed distribution of Fe active sites within the catalyst. In addition, the prepared graded Fe-Beta also had more Lewis acid sites, which also facilitated NH3 adsorption and activation. Therefore, the graded Fe-Beta catalysts were more active. Boroń et al. [186] prepared three Fe-BEA zeolite catalysts by two-step post-synthesis, ion-exchange and conventional wet impregnation methods, respectively. They compared the effects of these methods on the structure and properties of the catalysts. The activities of the Fe-BEA catalysts prepared by the impregnation and ion exchange methods were higher than those of the Fe-BEA catalysts prepared by the two-step post-synthesis method. And both pseudotetrahedral Al(III)-O(H)-Si and Fe(III)-O(H)-Si backbone sites were present in the first two catalysts, while only Fe(III)-O(H)-Si sites were present in the latter catalyst (Fig. 59 ). Thus, the acidity was also significantly higher than that of the catalyst prepared by the two-step post-synthesis method. The direct synthesis method is one of the more popular synthesis methods recently. The direct synthesis of Fe-Beta zeolites follows two different synthesis routes, in hydroxide and fluoride media, respectively[187]. Overall, the samples obtained by synthesizing in hydroxide media usually have smaller crystals and more structural defects, while the samples obtained by synthesizing in fluoride media have fewer defects and larger crystals[187]. Different Si/Al also affects the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Zhu et al. [184] used two types of Beta zeolites, an organic-free template-synthesized zeolite with a Si/Al ratio of 9, and a commercially available zeolite with a Si/Al ratio of 19, to synthesize Fe-Beta. The Fe-Beta catalyst with a Si/Al ratio of 9 exhibited significantly higher activity compared to the Fe-Beta catalyst with a Si/Al ratio of 19, especially at low temperatures (<250 °C). Fe-Beta (Si/Al=9) also demonstrated better hydrothermal stability during selective catalytic reduction (SCR) reactions due to its lower degree of dealumination during hydrothermal aging. In contrast, the commercial Beta zeolite experienced more severe dealumination, primarily caused by the instability of one of its framework Al atoms during hydrothermal treatment. The Fe-Beta (Si/Al=9) catalyst also has a high acidity, which further improves its catalytic activity as well. Martin et al. [187] also investigated the effect of different Si/Al ratios on the catalyst activity. A significant relationship was found between the Si/Al ratio of Fe-Beta catalysts and their catalytic activity, with NO conversion increasing with decreasing Si/Al ratio. This may be attributed to their smaller crystal size and greater tendency to form isolated Fe3+ in out-of-framework positions upon calcination. Sazama et al. [188] synthesized Al-rich template-free BEA zeolites (Si/Al = 4.6), which have a high concentration of Al-related active sites and a highly regular structure compared to conventional Si-rich Beta zeolites, which is directly reflected in the Enhanced activity. Lower content of alkali metal treatment can improve the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Liu et al. [189] discovered that Fe-Beta catalysts subjected to lower levels of potassium (K) deposition exhibited improved electron transfer, an increased Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio, and a higher relative content of reducing Fe species. These changes facilitated the adsorption of NO and O2, reduced the activation energy for the conversion of NO to NO2, and ultimately enhanced the catalytic activity of Fe-Beta. In addition, post-synthesis treatment of Fe-BEA with hydrogen has been shown to improve the low-temperature (< 300 °C) activity of the standard NH3-SCR process [190,191], but the high-temperature (> 400 °C) activity decreases slightly. Shawn's team[190] investigated the evolution of different Fe species in Fe-BEA before and after hydrogen treatment. It was found that after hydrogen treatment of Fe-BEA, larger Fe species (dimeric and oligomeric Fe species and Fe particles) were transformed into active isolated Fe species (Fig. 60 ). 3.3.2 Structure and active site The Fe-Beta catalyst is a BEA-type catalyst. both the MFI and BEA structures exhibit a multidirectional channel system (Fig. 61 ). ZSM-5 presents a 3D/10 meta-ring channel system, whereas Beta zeolite several hypothetical disordered symbionts of polycrystalline phenotypes, all of which are characterized by a 3D/12 meta-ring channel system[192]. As a result, the channel sizes in Beta (0.66 × 0.67 nm and 0.56 × 0.57 nm) are larger than those in ZSM-5 (0.53 × 0.56 nm and 0.51 × 0.55 nm). Doronkin et al. [193] found that the activity of Fe-Beta catalysts is determined by a relatively small fraction of isolated tetrahedral Fe3+ sites. Within the molecular sieves, different Fe species coexist, including isolated Fe3+ sites, oligomers, and large particles of polymers. Among these, the isolated Fe3+ and oligomeric FeO x species are the active sites for the selective catalytic reduction of NO x (NH3-SCR) in Fe-Beta catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 62 . Martin et al. [187] found that isolated Fe3+ located in the ion-exchange sites outside the different backbones of the Fe/Beta molecular sieve species exhibited different catalytic activities in NH3-SCR. Shi et al.
