[194] found that the addition of water to the NH3-SCR feed stream increased the activity of Fe-BEA and kept the selectivity at a high level. The promotion mechanism of water on the catalyst is mainly shown in Fig. 63 . In the absence of water addition, surface dehydration under reaction conditions makes the Lewis acid site the main active site of the catalyst. With the addition of water, the iron oxides in the catalyst in the presence of oxygen ions act as active sites for water reaction and vacancies for the generation of hydroxyl groups (OH-), converting the surface Lewis acid sites to Brønsted acid sites. These hydroxyl groups (Brønsted acid sites) are involved in the chemisorption of ammonia to form NH4 + ions, and the formation of these allows adsorption of NO3 −/NO2 − components, which in turn improves the activity of the catalyst at low temperatures. 3.3.3 Hydrothermal aging properties Hydrothermal aging can seriously affect the performance of catalysts. Gao et al. [195] found that hydrothermal aging leads to Fe ion aggregation and interactions between aluminum and iron species. Zhang et al. [196] also found that dealumination, loss of acidic sites, aggregation of active species, and disruption of the backbone structure of the Fe-Beta catalysts after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C for 24 h. In addition, through his research, he also found that The transition of [Fe2+-OX]+ to [HO-Fe3+-OX]+ during hydrothermal aging promotes the gradual dehydroxylation and condensation of [HO-Fe3+-OX]+, generating larger FeO x particles, which, in turn, affects the activity of the catalysts. Shawn et al. [197] found that the density of sites decreases after aging. However, the number of Fe and Brønsted acid sites is more affected by the aging process compared to Lewis acid sites. In addition, there were two Brønsted sites with different adsorption strengths in the Fe-Beta catalyst, and the stronger site was more sensitive to hydrothermal treatment compared to the weaker site. The hydrothermal aging temperature also has an impact on the performance of the catalyst. In general, the deactivation of catalysts is more pronounced with increasing aging temperature[198]. Shwan et al. [198] investigated the effect of aging time on the catalyst. The difference in aging time has two main effects: (i)short hydrothermal aging significantly reduces the storage capacity of ammonia and slightly increases the oxidation state of iron, which significantly reduces the oxidation state of NH3 and improves the oxidation state of NO but reduces the activity of the catalysts; (ii)long hydrothermal aging results in the formation of more obtained oxidation states of iron, which leads to a significant decrease in the activity of the low-temperature NH3-SCR. Smaller iron species (monomers and dimers) form oligomeric iron clusters after a short aging time. Conversely, longer thermal treatment times result in the formation of larger iron oxide particles. As shown in Fig. 64 , thermal aging in the absence of water has a similar effect, with mild aging leading to a decrease in the number of isolated iron species and the formation of oligomeric iron clusters in the zeolite pores, while more severe aging leads to continuous migration and the formation of larger iron oxide particles on the outer surface of the zeolite[199]. 3.3.4 P poisoning Shwan et al. [200] studied the effect of P poisoning on Fe-BEA catalysts. They exposed the prepared samples to 10 and 50 ppm phosphoric acid for 14, 24 and 48 h. It was found that the low-temperature (150∼300 °C) NH3-SCR activity of the catalysts after P-poisoning was drastically reduced and the degree of deactivation was strongly dependent on the phosphorus exposure time, with little effect of different concentrations of H3PO4. The chemical deactivation of the catalysts due to Fe-BEA exposure to phosphoric acid can be interpreted in two steps (Fig. 65 ): (i) During shorter phosphorus exposure times, phosphorus pentoxide (P2O5) with a relatively low content of metaphosphate (PO3 −) is formed. This does not affect NO x conversion but leads to an increase in the amount of strongly bound ammonia, which is inactive in the SCR reaction. (ii) Longer phosphorus exposure time leads to a continuous increase in the relative amount of metaphosphate and a decrease in the low-temperature active sites (Fe-O-OH) by substituting the hydroxyl groups on the active iron. 3.3.5 Alkali and alkaline earth metal poisoning The SCR activity of Fe-Beta catalysts was significantly reduced after K poisoning [189,201]. Liu et al. [189] discovered that high levels of K deposition have several detrimental effects on the catalyst. Firstly, K occupies the Brønsted acid sites, leading to the aggregation of reactive Fe species. Secondly, it increases the activation energy of NO oxidation on the Lewis acid sites. Additionally, K deposition results in the formation of inactive nitrates that can block the pore structure of Beta molecular sieves. As a result, the catalytically active Fe species are significantly reduced, leading to a decline in the catalytic activity of Fe-Beta catalysts. Shwan et al. [201] have found that Fe-BEA, after the influence of K, formed new NOx storage sites on the ammonia storage site of Brønsted acid, which increased the NOx storage capacity, but decreased the NH3 storage capacity. The interaction between Fe-BEA catalysts and K results in the formation of smaller trivalent iron clusters within the zeolite pores, causing the loss of active isolated iron species (Fig. 65). In addition, the deactivation of the catalyst is also related to the K content, which becomes more severe as the K content increases [189,201]. 4 Composite metal molecular sieve catalyst 4.1 Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 4.1.1 Preparation Cu-SSZ-13 performs well at low temperatures and Fe-SSZ-13 exhibits high NO x conversion at relatively high temperatures. Considering the respective advantages of Cu and Fe, attempts can be made to combine these two elements to overcome the deficiencies of a single metal and construct more efficient NH3-SCR catalysts over a wider temperature window[202]. Fe species can be introduced into Cu-SSZ-13 molecular sieves by ion exchange or impregnation, which is a traditional method of Fe doping. However, compared with the ionic size of transition metal Fe, since the Cu-SSZ-13 molecular sieve catalyst belongs to microporous molecular sieves, its pore size is around 0.38 nm × 0.38 nm, which is relatively small, which makes most of the Fe elements can only be dispersed on the surface of the molecular sieve but cannot enter the inside of the molecular sieve pore cages, which affects the Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 molecular sieve catalyst's NH3-SCR catalytic performance to some extent. It has been observed that around 10 % metal loading (Cu and Fe) is optimal for SCR activity, and the activity decreases after exceeding this loading [203]. Zhang et al. [204] prepared a series of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts by ion-exchange method on the basis of one-pot synthesis of Cu-SSZ-13 to investigate the effect of Fe loading on catalyst performance. It was found that the Fe1.32/Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst exhibited better catalytic performance. Wang et al. [202] also prepared Fe-Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts using the same method and considered the effects of Fe(NO3)3 concentration and exchange time on the catalyst activity. It was found that the best effect was achieved at the Fe/Cu ratio of 1.29, which not only maintained the excellent SCR activity of Cu-SSZ-13 at low temperatures (<200 °C), but also significantly improved its high-temperature activity. With the increase of Fe content, larger Fe2O3 particles appeared in the catalyst, which would block the zeolite pores or increase the NH3 oxidation capacity at high temperature, thus reducing the NO x removal efficiency of the catalyst. Different preparation methods have an impact on the performance of the catalysts. Yin et al. [203] found that introducing Fe through initial wet impregnation resulted in higher SCR activity compared to the traditional ion exchange method. Alkali impregnation can effectively improve the catalytic performance of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 [18,205]. As shown in Fig. 66 , Wu et al. [205] found that alkaline treatment had a significant effect on the crystallinity, acidity, redox properties, and coordination state of active Cu. The structure of zeolite remained intact after alkaline leaching, but the crystallinity was slightly decreased. Low-concentration alkaline treatment mainly destroys crystal fragments, and excessive alkaline leaching collapses cubic crystals. Appropriate alkaline leaching can promote the interaction of active metals with the zeolite skeleton, induce the formation of Lewis acid sites, significantly increase the redox capacity, and effectively promote the generation of Z2Cu. In addition, it significantly accelerated the reaction rate of adsorbed NO x with NH3 by promoting the generation of NO2 and the activation of NH3. When the NaOH concentration was 0.1 M, the synthesized catalyst exhibited enhanced catalytic activity, hydrothermal stability and good sulfur resistance compared with the commercial Cu-SSZ-13. Indeed, both metal loading and loading order have a great influence on the NH3-SCR performance of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts. Xie et al. [206] investigated the effect of loading order on the catalyst. It was found that the Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalyst prepared by loading Cu first and then Fe had the best catalytic activity as well as SO2 resistance ratio. Wang et al. [207] loaded Fe into one-pot synthesized Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts by SSIE, homogeneous deposition precipitation (HDP) and liquid ion exchange (IE), respectively. The Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts showed similar SO2 resistance and were all superior to the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. There were significant differences in the hydrothermal stability of the three Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts, which were related to the state of the active substances due to the different preparation methods. Compared with the other two catalysts, the Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 SSIE had more active substances distributed within the pores. These active substances tend to aggregate during hydrothermal treatment, leading to the collapse of the catalyst structure. As a result, Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 SSIE was almost inactivated after hydrothermal aging. On the contrary, the distribution of Fe on the surface of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 IE effectively inhibited the aggregation of active substances during aging and enhanced the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst. Xie et al. [206] prepared two iron-containing Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts (Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 and Cu-SSZ-13@Fe x O y ) by homogeneous precipitation and self-assembly methods, respectively, both of which exhibited excellent NH3-SCR reactivity and strong SO2 poisoning tolerance at low temperatures. In contrast, Cu-SSZ-13@Fe x O y prepared by the self-assembly method has a more specific internal Fe substance distribution and a distinct core-shell structure, but the Fe species within it is significantly lower than that of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13. 4.1.2 Structure and active site Wan et al. [208] analyzed the structure of the synthesized Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts and showed that the synthesized Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts have a typical CHA structure and good crystallinity. The isolated Cu2+ and monomeric Fe3+ were identified as the main Cu and Fe species. The results of activity evaluation showed that the Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts with appropriate Fe content possessed excellent activity over a wide temperature range. The enhanced catalytic performance of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 was attributed to the unique properties of the two active components, Cu and Fe. Isolated Cu2+ sites were identified as the primary active sites for the low-temperature SCR reaction, while monomeric Fe3+ sites provided effective active sites for the high-temperature SCR reaction [208,209]. The structure of zeolite remains unchanged after Fe doping of Cu-SSZ-13, and Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 possesses high redox properties and abundant iron morphology. It should be noted that excessive Fe doping can disrupt the zeolite structure, destroying the isolated Cu2+ sites and forming highly oxidized Fe2O3, which leads to a decrease in the catalytic performance. The samples of Cu/SSZ-13 appeared after Fe loading with active sites such as Fe3+ and FeO x , and there is a strong interaction between Fe and Cu, which results in favoring the activity of NH3-SCR, leading to a better redox capacity of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 over a wider temperature range than that of Cu-SSZ-13 [204,210]. In the study conducted by Zhang et al. [210], the distribution of Cu and Fe in Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts within SSZ-13 molecular sieves was determined. Py-IR results showed that Cu and Fe in Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts were mainly distributed in the cages of SSZ-13 crystals. The monomer Cu2+ ion coordinated with three oxygen atoms at the hexacyclic site of the Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalyst is the active Cu. Wang et al. [209] found that Cu1 was replaced at the ion-exchange site, and the structure of the zeolite skeleton collapsed. During the hydrothermal aging process, active Cu species migrated to more stable sites, while Cu/Fe agglomeration occured during SO2 pretreatment (Fig. 67 ). Wang et al. [202] found that Cu and Fe in the catalysts may exist as isolated ions or as highly dispersed small-sized oxide particles or amorphous forms. And a variety of active substances (ZCuOH, [Fe(OH)2]+, oligomeric iron clusters containing dimers) were present on the catalysts. ZCuOH can be used as an active site at low temperatures, whereas Cu2+ in the isolated D6R and Fe ion monomer/oligomer can be used as an active site at high temperatures. 4.1.3 Hydrothermal aging properties The doping of Fe to Cu-SSZ-13 has been shown to enhance the hydrothermal aging resistance of the catalyst [208,209]. Wan et al. [208] found that the temperature windows of NO x conversion of Cu-SSZ-13 molecular sieves, before and after hydrothermal aging, were 145 ∼ 490 °C and 160 ∼ 450 °C, respectively. In contrast, the NO x conversion temperature windows of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 molecular sieve catalysts, before and after hydrothermal aging, were 160 ∼ 580 °C and 205 ∼ 550 °C, respectively. These findings indicate that after undergoing hydrothermal aging treatment, Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 molecular sieve catalysts exhibited higher efficiency compared to Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. Although the low-temperature activity of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts was slightly inferior to Cu-SSZ-13, the high-temperature activity was improved. In general, the Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 molecular sieve catalyst had a wider activity window and better hydrothermal aging resistance. Zhang et al. [204] also investigated the impact of hydrothermal aging temperature on the catalysts and found that aging led to reduced NO conversion and activity across the entire temperature range, particularly at high temperatures. Hydrothermal aging also had a severe effect on the pore structure of the catalysts, resulting in decreased surface area and pore volume. At an aging temperature of 800 °C, the pore structure of the catalyst was nearly completely destroyed. However, when compared to Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts still exhibited higher activity at high temperatures, indicating an improved hydrothermal stability of the catalyst. 4.1.4 S poisoning The addition of Fe to Cu-SSZ-13 improved its resistance to SO2 poisoning [203,204,206]. Several studies have investigated the effects of Fe addition on the performance of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts under SO2 exposure. Wan et al. [208] observed that Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts, following SO2 pretreatment, exhibited a broader temperature range for NOx conversion compared to Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. However, the low-temperature activity of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts was poorer than that of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts, suggesting a trade-off between low- and high-temperature performance. Overall, the Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 molecular sieve catalyst displayed an expanded temperature range for optimal performance and exhibited superior resistance to sulfur poisoning. Zhang et al. [204] found that Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts exhibited improved water and sulfur resistance compared to Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. However, under the coexistence of water and SO2, the NO conversion of Cu-Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts rapidly decreased from 98 % to 86 %, and this decrease was almost irreversible. This was due to the formation of ammonium sulfate and copper sulfate on the catalyst surface, which blocked the active sites and led to permanent poisoning of the catalyst. Xie et al. [206] found that the addition of Fe species to Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts did not provide significant protection to Cu species during SO2 treatment. However, the retained active Fe species contributed to the activation of reactants, particularly the reaction between NH3 adsorbed species and NO x , resulting in better SO2 resistance compared to Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. For Cu-Fe/SSZ-13, the addition of Fe species did not significantly protect the Cu species during the SO2 treatment, but retained many active Fe species. In the presence of SO2, these species contribute to reactant activation, especially reactivity between NH3 adsorbed species and NO x , leading to better SO2 resistance than Cu-SSZ-13. 4.2 Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 4.2.1 Preparation According to previous studies, Cu-ZSM-5 has high NH3-SCR activity at medium temperature[211], while Fe-ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts have high reactivity at high temperature[174]. Obviously, combining the advantages of both, by incorporating copper and iron active sites in the ZSM-5 zeolite framework, molecular sieve catalysts (Fe-Cu/ZSM-5) with a wide temperature window can be obtained. In recent years, scholars have developed a variety of post-synthesis methods to prepare Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts, including physical mixing, wet impregnation, liquid or solid phase ion exchange, and chemical vapor deposition. However, different preparation methods have some effects on the activity, structure and metal morphology of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 68 , Jouini et al. [212] used solid-phase ion exchange, liquid-phase ion exchange and wet impregnation methods to prepare Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts. It was found that the liquid-phase ion-exchange method had significant metal losses in each preparation step, but it did not reduce the catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts, and the catalysts prepared by this method had the most homogeneous distribution of Fe and Cu species and were free from ammonia oxidation at high temperatures. On the other hand, the catalysts prepared by solid-phase ion exchange and wet impregnation methods had the highest metal content and higher number of oxide agglomerates, which led to a decrease in catalytic activity at high temperatures due to ammonia oxidation phenomenon. In addition, Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 zeolites prepared by physical mixing and wet impregnation methods usually exhibited low activity, poor stability, and reproducibility. Brandenberger et al. [213] found that Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by chemical vapor deposition have high activity and stability. However, this method was deemed costly and unsuitable for large-scale industrial applications. It can be seen that all conventional post-synthesis methods have more drawbacks, such as a significant decrease in crystallinity as well as specific surface area and pore volume, and the formation of inactive metal oxides. Therefore, the later developed one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method has become the best choice for the preparation of catalysts at present because of its simplicity of operation and high activity and selectivity of the prepared catalysts. Yue et al. [214] synthesized Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 bimetallic molecular sieves by a one-pot method using tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPABr) as a templating agent and ferric nitrate hydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O) and copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) as the sources of Cu and Fe, respectively. Compared with the catalysts prepared through wet impregnation, including Fe-ZSM-5, Cu ZSM-5 and Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts, it was found that Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 had more isolated Fe3+ in the ZSM-5 zeolite framework and a more uniform distribution of Cu. In addition, the synthesized Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 has a hierarchical pore structure with sizes ranging from 10 to 50 nm. Therefore, the Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance in NH3-SCR reaction. They displayed high NO conversion (>90 %) and N2 selectivity (∼100 %) over a wide temperature range of 230 to 500 °C, good hydrothermal stability and good SO2 tolerance. However, most one-pot hydrothermal synthesis methods usually require expensive templating agents, which hinder industrial applications due to high costs and environmental constraints. Therefore, a template-free one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method was developed. In the work by Yuan et al. [215], Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 sieves were prepared by direct hydrothermal synthesis using disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA-2Na-2H2O) chelated Cu2+ and Fe3+ precursors as metal sources. It was found that the zeolite catalysts prepared by this method exhibited superior catalytic performance for NH3-SCR over a wide temperature range of 220 to 480 °C. These catalysts outperformed the Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts typically prepared by the impregnation method. In addition, the catalysts showed high stability and good resistance to H2O and SO2. And compared to the conventional post-synthesis route, the direct hydrothermal synthesis method using EDTA-2Na-2H2O as the chelating agent for the metal precursors was more efficient and reproducible, and the synthesized Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 molecular sieves, Cu2+/Cu+ and Fe3+/Fe2+, showed better dispersion of both species (Fig. 69 ). Jouini et al. [216] found that the order in which the metal ions were exchanged affected the number of metal species obtained, the degree of aggregation and the environment, which led to differences in the catalytic behavior of the SCR reaction. The activity of exchanging Fe followed by Cu is slightly higher than that of exchanging Cu followed by Fe. This is due to the fact that the addition of Cu promotes the aggregation of Fe substances and hence better performance is obtained. Similar conclusions were reached by Asima et al. [217]. The Cu and Fe content of the catalysts also affects the activity of the catalysts. Denardin et al. [218] found that the acid strength increased with increasing Cu loading. Asima et al. [217] prepared a series of Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts with a fixed Fe content and variable Cu content using a solid state ion exchange method. It was found that with increasing Cu loading at constant Fe loading, the low-temperature activity of the catalysts (<350 °C) was increased and the high-temperature activity of the catalysts was decreased, but the increase in the low-temperature activity was not as significant as the decrease in the high-temperature activity. In addition, small amounts of Cu were sufficient to increase the low temperature NO x conversion without significantly affecting the high temperature performance. By adjusting the amount of Cu and Fe, the reducibility of the catalyst can be adjusted, which in turn can change the temperature window of the catalyst. Zhang et al. [219] synthesized a series of Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts with fixed Cu content and variable Fe loading by impregnation method. It was found that the best performance was achieved with Fe loading of 4 wt %, while large Fe additions (6 wt %, 8 wt %) led to a decrease in activity, which could be related to the non-selective oxidation of NH3. Whereas, the catalytic activity was independent of the different Fe contents in the catalyst in the temperature range of 200 to 375 °C (Fig. 70 ). 4.2.2 Structure and active site The Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalyst showed a wider conversion window for NO x compared to the single metal exchanged ZSM-5 catalyst. Zhang et al. [219] found that Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts contain the following active sites that may be associated with Cu and Fe species. Among them, Cu species were mainly present in the form of highly dispersed CuO x nanoparticles and isolated Cu2+ ions, and Fe species were present in the form of aggregated Fe2O3 species, FeO x oligomers, and oxo-Fe3+. both oxo-Fe3+ and oligo-Fe oxides promoted NH3-SCR, and the latter had a higher intrinsic activity. Yue et al. [214] summarized the reasons for the high activity of Fe-Cu/ZSM-5: (i) the presence of more isolated tetrahedrally coordinated Cu2+ species, which act as active sites for the NH3-SCR reaction, have good low-temperature activity and inhibit the side reactions at higher temperatures; (ii) the high-temperature activity is provided by the Fe3+ species in the zeolite skeleton; (iii) a hierarchical micromicellar structure can greatly improve the accessibility of active sites. The coexistence of Fe and Cu in Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts brings about several beneficial effects. Firstly, it results in changes in electronic properties, enhancing the catalyst's redox capacity and generating a greater number of acid sites compared to catalysts with a single metal component [216,218]. The interaction between Fe and Cu in Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts modifies the electronic properties, enhances redox capacity, and increases in the number of strong acidic acid sites on the surface of the catalysts, surpassing those observed in Cu-ZSM-5 catalysts [217,219]. Therefore, the addition of Fe improved the catalytic performance of Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst. Furthermore, the introduction of Cu improves the low-temperature activity of Fe due to its reduced nature. When Cu is bonded to Fe at the same site, it induces charge depletion in Fe, strengthening the acidity[218]. Denardin et al. [218] showed an increase in the stability of the reduced form of Fe when bonded to Cu as determined by DFT calculations. Zhang et al. [219] concluded that the presence of Fe affects the dispersion of Cu, that the interaction between Fe and Cu species prevents the harmful aggregation of Cu species, reduces the number of blocked micropores, the surface area and pore volume of the catalyst increases. Additionally, Fe and Cu elements on the surface of the Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts form an Fe-Cu nanocomposite. The high dispersion of Fe and Cu species on the catalyst surface contributes to the improved performance of the catalyst, enabling high NO conversion (>90 %) in the temperature range of 200 to 475 °C. 4.2.3 Hydrothermal aging properties Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 has good hydrothermal stability. Jouini et al. [220] found that after hydrothermal treatment of Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts at 850 °C, the BET surface area and micropore volume of the aged samples decreased slightly compared to fresh samples. The catalyst undergoes partial dealumination during hydrothermal aging, but the catalyst structure is not destroyed, and the deactivation of the catalyst is due to the modification of the metal sites that catalyze the SCR reaction. In addition, they found that copper oxide clusters were responsible for the decrease in SCR activity of aged Fe-Cu/ZSM-5[221]. 4.2.4 S poisoning Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 also has good SO2 resistance. Yuan et al. [215] investigated the effect of SO2 and water on Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 71 . Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 zeolite showed good stability at 350 °C, and the NO x conversion of the zeolite was more than 98 %, and in the presence of water vapor or SO2 alone, there was little change in the catalyst activity. When water vapor and SO2 were introduced at the same time, the NO x conversion decreased slightly from 99 % to 95 %. This is because when water vapor is present in the reaction system, SO2 first reacts with some ammonia in the active sites to form ammonium sulfate, which poisons the active zone and reduces the catalytic efficiency of the catalyst. However, the poisoning is temporary and its catalytic activity can be recovered better after stopping the supply of water vapor and SO2. Therefore, the Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 zeolite has high stability and good resistance to H2O and SO2 during the reaction process. 4.2.5 Alkali metal poisoning In the study conducted by Jouini et al. [222], the effect of alkali metal poisoning on Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts was investigated. Specifically, the elements sodium (Na) and potassium (K) were introduced into fresh catalysts, and their impact on the catalyst activity was examined. The results showed that the introduction of Na and K had a detrimental effect on the activity of Fe-Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts. Interestingly, K exhibited a stronger inhibitory effect on catalytic activity at low temperatures compared to Na, which was the opposite of Na's effect. This is mainly due to the fact that the addition of Na promotes the agglomeration of Fe and Cu particles, neutralizes more strong acid sites, and the reduction of surface acidity leads to a significant decrease in the catalyst activity in the high temperature range. In addition, the introduction of Na and K did not reduce the crystallinity and structural properties (specific surface area and pore volume) of the zeolite, but resulted in a new mesoporosity of the ZSM-5 material. 4.3 Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 4.3.1 Preparation The Cu-SAPO-34 zeolite catalyst mentioned earlier is a highly efficient catalyst for denitrogenation, exhibiting with a wide temperature range and excellent high temperature hydrothermal stability. However, this catalyst also has the disadvantage of being highly susceptible to deactivation by water vapor at low temperatures. Therefore, Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts generally do not have excellent low temperature catalytic activity. In this case, Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 was developed and applied to denitrification reactions. Generally, loading the active component can be done by conventional post-synthesis methods, such as ion exchange, conventional impregnation, and so on. However, these preparation methods have disadvantages. They mainly include: (i) the dispersion of active components in SAPO-34-based catalysis cannot be effectively controlled; (ii) the preparation process is cumbersome and generally requires more than two steps; (iii) it is difficult to determine the optimal amount of active components, and the precursors of active components used in the preparation process are easily lost. To overcome these drawbacks, the one-pot synthesis method is commonly employed for the synthesis of Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 catalysts. This approach offers several advantages. It allows for improved control over the dispersion of active components, simplifies the preparation process, and reduces the loss of precursor materials. Huang et al. [223] prepared Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 samples by a one-pot synthesis method as shown in Fig. 72 . It is also easy to see from the figure that for the Mn-SAPO-34 and Cu-SAPO-34 samples, the low-temperature NH3-SCR activities of these two catalysts are not good. In contrast, Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 showed excellent low-temperature NH3-SCR activity (conversion >90 %) in the range of 160∼300 °C. Liu et al. [224] prepared Cu-SAPO-34, Mn-SAPO-34 and Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 catalyst samples by impregnation method, and came to a similar conclusion. Liu et al. [224] investigated the effect of Mn loading on the activity of Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 catalysts and found that the activity of the catalysts first increased and then decreased with the increase of Mn content. However, at temperatures above 270 °C, the activity of catalysts with more than 8 % Mn content decreased significantly. This phenomenon can be attributed to the enhanced oxidation performance of the catalysts at high temperatures, which is associated with the increased Mn loading. The enhanced oxidation leads to the conversion of NH3 to NO, resulting in a decrease in NO conversion. This is related to the aggregation of Mn species leading to the lack of MNO x and the reduction of Brønsted acid sites[225]. Zhao et al. [226] prepared Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 catalysts by liquid-phase ion-exchange and investigated the effect of different Cu/Mn ratios on the catalytic activity, and found that the catalysts were the most active when the Cu/Mn ratio was 3:2 (Fig. 73 ). Jiang et al. [227] evaluated the effect of Cu/Mn molar ratio on catalytic activity at low temperatures (160 °C) and found that the optimal Cu/Mn molar ratio was 10:5. 4.3.2 Structure and active site Previously, we have known that the active site on Cu-SAPO-34 is isolated Cu2+. For Mn-SAPO-34, Liu et al. [228] found that Mn3+ and Mn4+ species in the catalyst were the main active sites for the NH3-SCR reaction of Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst. In addition, the Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst formed MNO x species on the surface, which enhanced NO oxidation and introduced more Lewis acid sites, which facilitated the fast SCR reaction. Pang et al. [225] found that manganese species could be converted from Mn2+ to Mn3+ or Mn4+ in zeolite channels and were mainly distributed on the outer surface of the catalyst. The low-temperature NH3-SCR activities of the mechanically mixed Mn-SAPO-34 and Cu-SAPO-34 samples alone were also not as effective as those of the Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 molecular sieve catalysts, which suggests that there is a strong interaction between the Mn- and Cu-activated species in the catalysts. Liu et al. [224] proposed that the bimetallic interactions between Cu and Mn may reduce the energy for the denitrogenation reaction, thus increasing the low-temperature activity of the catalyst and broadening its SCR temperature range. Huang et al. [229] later found that when Cu and Mn were doped together, most of the crystalline physical structures in SAPO-34 remained unchanged and, due to the co-doping of Cu and Mn, the number of active centers on the surface of the catalyst (Cu+ and Cu2+) was increased, and the acid strength of the catalyst surface was increased with the increase of NH3 and NO x adsorption also increased. Thus Cu-Mn-SAPO-34 exhibited high denitrogenation activity and stability over the whole temperature range. Overall, Mn and Cu species were highly dispersed on the surface of the SAPO-34 carrier, preserving the crystal structure of SAPO-34 and creating a synergistic effect. The co-loading of Cu-Mn facilitated the transformation of Cu2+ to Cu+ and increased the proportion of high-valent Mn4+ and Mn3+, which enhanced low-temperature activity and facilitated the catalytic reaction. 4.3.3 Hydrothermal aging properties The Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 catalyst has good hydrothermal stability. Cheng et al. [230] also investigated the Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 catalyst after hydrothermal aging treatment and by DRIFTS experiments, and found that the hydrothermal aging treatment has almost no negative impact on NH3 adsorption, and it promotes NH3 adsorption. In addition, more NO2 was adsorbed on the hydrothermally aged catalysts compared to fresh Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 and related intermediates could be formed. Liu et al. [224] investigated the effect of H2O on Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 molecular sieve catalysts. It was found that the addition of H2O resulted in a decrease in catalyst activity, and this poisoning effect becomes more obvious with the increase of water concentration, but this poisoning effect on the catalyst is reversible. And the main causal effect of catalyst poisoning will become less important, when the temperature is higher than 300 °C, the effect of water can be ignored. The addition of H2O does not damage the skeleton of SAPO-34, but it will lead to the reduction of the specific surface area and pore size of the catalyst, which is also related to the concentration of the added water and the temperature of the reaction, with the increase of the concentration, the effect will become more serious, with the increase of the temperature, the effect becomes lighter. The presence of H2O diminished the catalyst's activity, with the effect becoming more pronounced as the water concentration increased. The reversible poisoning effect of H2O is mainly due to the competitive adsorption of H2O and NH3 on the Lewis acid sites by occupying the metal sites. The poisoning effect diminishes with increasing reaction temperature. Huang et al. [223] investigated the effect of water on Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 and Mn-SAPO-34. They prepared the catalysts in question using a one-pot synthesis method and subjected them to an environment containing 10 % water vapor for the catalytic reaction, where the effect of water stabilizes as the reaction time progresses. A comparison between the two properties revealed that the introduction of Cu could improve the water resistance of the catalysts. 4.3.4 S poisoning The Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 catalyst exhibited good resistance to SO2. S poisoning deactivation was attributed to the deposition of large amounts of ammonium sulfate, which was deposited on the active sites and inhibited NH3 adsorption. Liu et al. [224] found that some of the active sites on the catalyst after the passage of SO2 were occupied by SO2. Some active sites were temporarily occupied by SO2, causing temporary poisoning, while a significant number of active sites were covered by the formed sulfate (such as ammonium sulfate), leading to permanent deactivation of the catalyst. SO2 also caused a decrease in the specific surface area and pore size of the catalysts, and this damage was related to the concentration of SO2 and the temperature of the reaction. As the reaction temperature increases, the damage to the surface area caused by SO2 gradually decreases. In addition, the poisoning effect of NH3-SCR activity depends on the reaction temperature. At low temperatures, the poisoning effect of SO2 is permanent and there is deposition of (NH4)2SO4 or NH4HSO4 on the active sites. These metal sulfates formed on the catalyst surface also inhibit the redox properties and cut off the redox cycle during the low temperature SCR reaction, which in turn reduces the activity of the catalyst. At higher reaction temperatures, the formation of ammonium sulfate was inhibited due to its tendency to decompose at high temperatures. In addition, the simultaneous action of water and SO2 has a greater impact on the catalyst performance. The addition of H2O has the following two effects: (i) SO2 in the gas phase reacts with H2O adsorbed on the catalyst active site to generate sulfuric or sulfurous acid that reacts readily with NH3; (ii) it restricts the thermal decomposition of the ammonium sulfate generated on the active center. Thus, the rapid decrease in denitrogenation activity catalyst structure is more damaged. When only SO2 was present, NH4HSO4, (NH4)2SO4, and MnSO4 were observed, while in the presence of both water and SO2, (NH4)2SO4 and CuSO4 were formed. 4.4 Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 4.4.1 Preparation As mentioned before, Cu-SAPO-34 belongs to copper-modified CHA-type molecular sieve, which shows promise as SCR catalyst due to its microporous structure, moderate acidity, and high hydrothermal stability. It exhibits high denitrogenation activity in diesel exhaust treatment above 200 °C, but its low-temperature activity and stability remain unsatisfactory. The low-temperature catalytic activity of SCR catalysts based on monometallic modified molecular sieves needs to be further improved. Rare earth modification is an effective method to improve the stability and activity of zeolite catalysts. Cu-SAPO-34 modified by Ce doping has better catalytic activity and stability. Guan et al. [231] found that compared to Cu-SAPO-34, Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 exhibited higher catalytic activity throughout the entire temperature range, especially at temperatures below 250 °C and above 400 °C. The synthesis method has an important effect on the structure and performance of the catalyst. Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts can be prepared using post-synthesis methods such as ion-exchange and impregnation. Cao et al. [232] utilized a wet impregnation method to prepare Ce-Cu/SAPO-34, which exhibited excellent low-temperature activity. However, the X-ray diffraction (XRD) results indicated that the crystallinity of catalysts prepared using this method still needs improvement. Qiu et al. [233] synthesized Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 by a one-step hydrothermal method, which maintained good crystallinity and the ortho-hexahedral appearance of Cu-SAPO-34, while having a higher specific surface area and pore volume. Different templating agents also have an effect on Ce-Cu/SAPO-34. Qiu et al. [233] demonstrated variations in the performance of Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 molecular sieves prepared using TEA, MOR and TEAOH as templating agents, respectively. All three catalysts exhibited NO x conversion rates of over 90 % in the temperature range of 200∼350 °C, but the Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst prepared with MOR as the templating agent showed higher SCR activity compared to the others. The length of crystallization time also affects the performance of the catalysts. The catalysts synthesized with a crystallization time of 60 h displayed the highest NO x conversion, surpassing 95 % in the temperature range of 200 ∼ 350 °C. Catalysts prepared with a crystallization time of 72 h achieved an NOx conversion of 80 %. On the other hand, samples prepared with 48 h of crystallization showed the weakest performance, with NOx conversion below 80 % at each temperature point [233]. The loading amount of Ce also affects the catalytic activity and stability of Ce-Cu-SAPO-34. Appropriate Ce content is favorable to improve the catalytic activity of the catalyst, while too much Ce may lead to decreased selectivity [231,233]. When the dopant Ce species of Cu-SAPO-34 exceeded 0.04 % (by mass), the Ce species exhibited a slight inhibitory effect on the catalytic performance and the NO x conversion was reduced. Qiu et al. [233] determined the optimum loading to be 0.02 % (by mass). Zhang et al. [234] found that a sufficient Ce loading (2 wt % and 4 wt %) significantly improved the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34, while catalysts with low/no cerium loading were susceptible to water erosion under low-temperature hydrothermal aging conditions. Mao et al. [235] concluded that increasing Ce loading improves the high-temperature hydrothermal stability of the catalysts and reduced the negative effects of hydrothermal aging. They further determined that catalysts with a Cu/Ce mass ratio of 4:5 exhibit the best hydrothermal stability. Higher Ce loading results in more stable catalyst structure, improved distribution of active Cu species on the catalyst surface, and higher content of isolated Cu2+. In summary, we can determine the optimal conditions for the preparation of Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 by one-pot synthesis with MOR as templating agent, 0.02 % mass fraction of Ce and 72 h crystallization time. 4.4.2 Structure and active site In Cu-Ce/SAPO-34, Ce3+ and Ce4+ species are present along with isolated Cu2+. However, they are only present on the surface of Cu-SAPO-34[234]. Ce4+ is believed to originate from CeO2, while Ce3+ is thought to be located on the acid sites of the Cu-SAPO-34 surface. Analogous to Cu-Mn/SAPO-34, there must be a strong interaction between Cu and Ce in Ce-Cu/SAPO-34, rather than a simple binding[236]. Recent research by scholars has shed light on the interaction between Cu and Ce, which can be summarized as follows (Fig. 74 ): (i) promotion of the ion exchange process: This facilitates the generation of more beneficial active sites, increases surface acidity, and stabilizes surface acidic sites [233,236,237]. It also leads to the formation of more monodentate nitrate adsorption sites, which aids in the adsorption and activation of reactants [231,236,237]; (ii) inhibition of Cu ion accumulation: This prevents the accumulation of Cu ions on the surface and the formation of copper oxides [231,237], resulting in the presence of more isolated Cu2+ active sites and fewer CuO x species; (iii) promotion of the formation of ZCuOH sites: This limits the over-oxidation of NH3 and facilitates the formation of more ZCuOH sites for copper oxides [231]; (iv) well-dispersed Cu ions and lower Cu-O bond strengths: This enhances the redox capacity of the catalyst [231,233,236,237]. In addition, after Ce species doping, the CHA topology of Cu-SAPO-34 molecular sieves is comple, te, retaining the full orthotetrahedral structure and maintaining the relatively large specific surface area and uniform pore size distribution of Cu-SAPO-34 [233,237]. 4.4.3 Hydrothermal ageing properties Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 exhibits superior hydrothermal stability compared to Cu-SAPO-34, thanks to the introduction of cerium species into the catalyst. This incorporation of cerium enhances the catalyst's the low-temperature hydrothermal stability of the catalyst for the NH3-SCR reaction [231,233]. The interaction between Ce and Cu protects the main reaction sites during low-temperature hydrothermal aging and mitigates the impact of hydrothermal aging on catalysts effects of hydrothermal aging on the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 75 , the aging defense mechanism of cerium acts as a protective shield and ion exchange. The Ce co-cation forms a protective shield on the catalyst's surface, reinforcing the framework and safeguarding the internal Cu active sites by preferentially undergoing erosion during low-temperature hydrothermal aging. In addition, the Ce co-cation protects the Si-O(H)-Al bonds by exchanging H ions to form Si-O(Ce)-Al bonds, thereby preventing dealumination process[231]. Guan et al. [231] found that the Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 samples that had undergone aging exhibited higher efficiency below 400 °C compared to the aged Ce-SAPO-34 samples. Furthermore, the aged Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts outperformed the fresh Cu-Ce/SAPO-34 samples below 250 °C (Fig. 75). In addition, the increase in Brønsted acid sites after aging of the Ce-modified Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts could be attributed to the shedding of Ce from the Si-O(Ce)-Al bonds, which released the Si-O(H)-Al bonds. The catalyst retained a large number of Cu sites after the low-temperature hydrothermal aging treatment. Not only that, the aged catalyst still maintains excellent physicochemical properties and structural integrity. Zhang et al. [234] also observed good stability of freshly prepared Cu-Ce/SAPO-34 catalysts using the impregnation method, followed by hydrothermal treatment at 70 °C and 80 % relative humidity for 4 days. The defective sites of Cu-SAPO-34, which tend to exist at the surface, were filled by cerium ions after the introduction of Ce, improving the original CHA structure. In addition, the loading of Ce resulted in a decrease in surface acidity and improves the stability of the CHA structure. The above two points resulted in a more complete CHA structure of the prepared Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts, avoiding the additional loss of CuII ions instead of the spontaneous hydrolysis of CuII ions to form inactive substances (Cu-Al, CuO x and Cu(OH)2). High-temperature hydrothermal aging has been observed to reduce the NO x conversion efficiency of Cu-Ce/SAPO-34 catalysts. Mao et al. [235] conducted a study in which freshly prepared Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 samples were subjected to hydrothermal aging in a 10 vol % H2O/N2 environment at 750 °C for 8 h. It was observed that, despite retaining the CHA structure, the catalysts exhibited rough and adhesive crystalline surfaces after high-temperature hydrothermal aging. The effects of high-temperature hydrothermal aging on the catalyst were as follows: (i) the reduction of Cu active material in the catalyst and the aggregation of Ce and Cu species to form CeO2 and CuO x led to non-selective oxidation side reactions; (ii) the conversion of Ce3+ to Ce4+ was promoted, which reduced the oxygen pore concentration of the catalyst, thus decreasing the reactivity of the SCR reaction; and (iii) some of the acid sites on the surface of the catalyst were destroyed. Fan et al. [237] found that the addition of Ce significantly improved the hydrothermal stability of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst (hydrothermal aging in 10 vol % H2O /air at 700 °C for 10 h). Prior to hydrothermal aging, the NH3-SCR reactions on fresh Cu-SAPO-34 and Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts followed the L-H and Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanisms, and after hydrothermal aging, the "E-R" reaction route was inhibited on the aged Cu-SAPO-34 due to the severe structural damage caused by hydrothermal aging. However, the "E-R" and "L-H" reaction routes can still proceed smoothly on aged Ce-Cu/SAPO-34. 4.4.4 S poisoning Compared to Cu-SAPO-34, the Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst has a superior resistance to S poisoning [238,239]. Ge et al. [238] loaded Ce onto Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts using wet impregnation to mitigate sulfur toxicity. As shown in Fig. 77, although the low-temperature activity of the S-poisoned samples decreased compared to the fresh samples, the presence of Ce significantly enhanced the low-temperature activity of the S-poisoned samples. In addition, the zeolite framework of the Ce-Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst was less affected by the cerium and sulfur species after S poisoning. And compared with Cu-SAPO-34, Cu-Ce/SAPO-34 has a larger BET surface area. From the previous section, it can be inferred that the anti-S mesotoxicity of Z2Cu is higher than that of ZCuOH, and the high relative content of Z2Cu is also found in Cu-Ce-SAPO-34. Therefore, it can be concluded that the main contribution of Ce in the mitigating S toxicity is the ratio regulating and protective effect: (i) reduction of the S content, which reduces the amount of sulfate deposition in the zeolite framework; and (ii) facilitation of the formation of Z2Cu, which improves the Z2Cu ratio. Fig. 78 shows the mechanism of Ce enhancing the sulfur resistance of Cu-SAPO-34, along with a brief summary of the NH3-SCR reaction process. 4.4.5 Alkali and alkaline earth metal poisoning In a study by Wang et al. [240], it was concluded that copper-based catalysts promoted with cerium (Cu-Ce/SAPO-34) have excellent resistance to alkali (K) and alkaline earth (Ca) poisoning. CeO2-modified catalysts can accelerate the redox cycling of Cu ions and promote the trapping of Ca by SAPO-34. The cerium-modified Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst prevents the irreversible binding of K and Ca to the active sites, giving the catalyst excellent anti-poisoning properties. Ce is an effective oxidative additive that promotes electron transfer effects with the Cu active site, improves redox cycling, and exhibits a clear potential to bind to Ca poisons and enhance resistance. At the same time, the addition of K or Ca generates new base sites on the catalyst, which promotes the adsorption of reactive NO x (Fig. 79). 5 NH3-SCR mechanism The NH3-SCR mechanism reveals the gradual conversion of NH3, NO x and other reactive species to products (N2 and H2O) on the catalyst surface. This process relies on the participation of active species, such as acid sites on the catalyst, and also involves the transport of intermediate species. Fig. 80 provides a visual representation of the mechanism. It is important to note that different molecular sieve catalysts may possess different active sites, structures and acidity, etc. As a result, the corresponding NH3-SCR reaction mechanisms can vary. Hence, it is extremely important to study the corresponding NH3-SCR reaction mechanism. Such studies can provide valuable insights for guiding the synthesis of new molecular sieve catalysts tailored for NH3-SCR applications. Depending on the proportion of NO and NO2 in NO x , the NH3-SCR reaction can be categorized into standard NH3-SCR, fast NH3-SCR reaction and NO2-SCR (slow SCR). The standard NH3-SCR reaction (Eq. 1) dominates when the NO x is all NO and the reaction temperature is lower than 400 °C. At lower temperatures, when NO:NO2 = 1:1, the fast NH3-SCR reaction (Eq. 2) occurs, rapidly increasing the NO x conversion[242]. (1) 4NO + 4NH3 + O2 = 4N2 + 6H2O (2) NO + 2NH3 + NO2 = 2N2 + 3H2O When the NO2 concentration in the feed gas is high (NO2/NO x > 0.5), NH3 and NO2 can react to form NH4NO3 at temperatures below 200 °C (Eq. 3): (3) 2NH3 + 2NO2 = NH4NO3 + N2 + H2O When the reaction temperature in NH3-SCR exceeds 300 °C, side reactions such as non-selective catalytic reduction (reaction 4) and catalytic oxidation (reactions 5, 6, and 7) of NH3 occur [241,243]. (4) 4NH3 + 4NO + 3O2 = 4N2O + 6H2O (5) 4NH3 + 5O2 = 4NO + 6H2O (6) 4NH3 + 7O2 = 4NO2 + 6H2O (7) 4NH3 + 3O2 = 2N2 + 6H2O In addition, oxidation of NO also occurs, primarily resulting in the formation of NO2, while NH3 is oxidized to N2, NO, NO2, and N2O (>400 °C). It is worth noting that increasing the reaction temperature enhances the side reactions of oxidation in NH3-SCR reaction. Consequently, there is a desire to enhance reactions 1 and 2 and weaken 4-6 (referring to the desired reactions, Fig. 81). The objective is to maximize the conversion of NO x into N2 while minimizing the formation of undesired byproducts. Ammonium nitrate can decompose to N2O (Eq. 8). However, ammonium nitrate does not decompose easily at low temperatures, which can cover the active sites on the catalyst surface and lead to catalyst deactivation. (8) NH4NO3 + 3O2 = 2N2 + 6H2O The NO2-SCR reaction occurs when the NO x in the feed gas is all NO2: (9) 6NO2 = N2O + 2H2O The NH3-SCR reaction at low temperatures mainly proceeds through the L-H mechanism, wherein NO and NH3 are simultaneously adsorbed on the catalyst surface. This interaction generates reactive intermediates that subsequently undergo decomposition to produce N2 and H2O. As shown in Fig. 82, in the L-H mechanism, NO is oxidized by high-valent redox sites, leading to the formation of reactive di-dentate nitrate, bridged nitrate, or monodentate nitrite species, which then react with NH4 + (formed from NH3 adsorption on acidic sites) to form NH4NO2 or NH4NO3, which finally decomposes to N2 and H2O. Throughout this process, the valence of the redox sites decreases, followed by an increase through O2 oxidation, thereby completing the redox cycle. In contrast, high-temperature NH3-SCR reactions predominantly follow the E-R mechanism, in which NH3 is initially adsorbed on acidic sites, forming NH3 or NH4 +. Subsequently, NO oxidizes NH3 or NH4 + to form the reactive intermediate NH2NO or NH3NO, which finally decomposes into N2 and H2O [244]. Qin et al. [245] compared the differences in the E-R and L-H mechanisms on Cu-SSZ-13 and Fe-SSZ-13, and the results are shown in Figs. 83 and 84. Cu-SSZ-13 exhibits a higher concentration of Lewis acid sites, whereas there are more Brønsted acid sites in Fe-SSZ-13. The adsorption activity of NH3 on Lewis acid sites is much higher than that on Brønsted acid sites, enabling the former to react directly and rapidly with NO, while the latter exhibits slower reactivity. These differences between Cu-SSZ-13 and Fe-SSZ-13 contribute to variations in their NH3-SCR reactions. When Cu-SSZ-13 performs the E-R reaction mechanism, NH3 and NO co-adsorb on the active Cu sites to form NH2NO, which subsequently decomposes into N2 and H2O. In Fe-SSZ-13, NH3 adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites reacts with the NO3 − (formed via NO oxidation) on the Fe active sites to form NH4NO2. In Cu-SSZ-13, during the L-H mechanism, NO is activated at Cu2+ to form NO3 −, which then reacts with NO to form NO2 −. Furthermore, NO3 − reacts with NH3 adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites to produce NH4NO2. In contrast, the two reaction steps illustrated in Fig. 82 will occur in Fe-SSZ-13. Cu-SSZ-13 predominantly features NO3 − as the main nitrate species, while Fe-SSZ-13 has NO3 − and NO2 − as the main nitrate species. Therefore, the NH3-SCR reaction on Cu-SSZ-13 follows both the E-R and the L-H mechanisms, with the L-H mechanism route exhibiting a faster reaction rate. Conversely, Fe-SSZ-13 primarily operates through the E-R mechanism. Zhu et al. [246] discovered that during standard SCR reaction conditions, NO exhibits a faster reaction rate with adsorbed NH3 on Cu active sites in Cu-SSZ-13 compared to Cu-SSZ-39, resulting in lower standard SCR activity for Cu-SSZ-39. Conversely, under fast SCR conditions, NO can rapidly reduce NH4NO3 on the acid sites of Cu-SSZ-39, thereby promoting the SCR activity, while the slow reaction between NH4NO3 and NO on Cu-SSZ-13 leads to the accumulation of NH4NO3 and pore blockage, resulting in suppressed activity (Fig. 85). The surface's Brønsted acidic sites play a key role in the reduction of surface NH4NO3 by NO, and the surface acidity of Cu-SSZ-39 is significantly higher than that of Cu-SSZ-13. This allows NO to rapidly reduce NH4NO3 on Cu-SSZ-39, even faster than the reduction of NO by NH3 adsorbed on the Cu active sites. Additionly, they[111] suggested that below 200 °C, the L-H mechanism operates on Cu-SSZ-39, whereas above 200 °C, the adsorbed NH3 reacts directly with gaseous NO, and the E-R mechanism dominates. Yu et al. [247] concluded that O2 plays an important role in the oxidation of NO and the regeneration of Cu2+ sites, which significantly enhances the NH3-SCR activity. NH3 can be adsorbed on the Brønsted and Lewis (formation of Cu2+-(NH3) species) acid sites. In the absence of O2, at the Cu2+ site, NO is initially oxidized to NO2 by skeletal oxygen, followed by the reaction of NO2 with adsorbed NH3 species to form ammonium nitrate/ammonium nitrite. Ammonium nitrate decomposes to form N2O, while ammonium nitrite serves as an intermediate, decomposing nitrogen and water. Therefore, the oxidation of NO is crucial and serves as the key and rate-determining step to prevent the formation of ammonium nitrate. Furthermore, the mechanism of NH3-SCR and NH3 oxidation on Cu-SAPO-34 was summarized and the results are depicted in Fig. 86. Mao et al. [248] revealed the mechanisms of both standard NH3-SCR and fast NH3-SCR reactions performed on Cu-SAPO-34, as illustrated in Fig. 87. For the standard SCR reaction, NO and NH3 are initially co-adsorbed on the Cu2+ site, leading to the formation of NH2NO through N-N coupling, while the CuII site is reduced to CuI. Subsequently, NO is oxidized by O2, and NH3 continues to be adsorbed on the Cu+ site to generate NH4 +, which produces NH4NO2, and at the same time, oxidized CuI to CuII, which left O atoms on the Cu site. After that, the O atoms further oxidize NO to NO2, and the CuII site transforms into pure Cu2+. Finally, NH4NO2 and NH2NO decompose into N2 and H2O. In the fast SCR reaction, the process of CuI returning to CuII site, which is the process of generating NH4NO2, appears somewhat different. NO2 directly adsorbs on Cu+ and reacts with NH3 to generate NH4NO2, and at the same time oxidizes CuI to pure Cu2+. During the process of the above reaction, the effective free energy barrier for NO oxidation is the highest (0.86 eV), which can be considered as the rate-limiting step. In addition, it can be observed from the mechanism that standard SCR reaction involves two essential processes: NO activation (coupling with NH3) and NO oxidation, which are closely related to ensure the completion of the overall reaction, while fast SCR reaction does not require the process of NO oxidation, resulting in a faster reaction rate. Li et al. [124] proposed a cycle path for standard SCR reaction and fast SCR reaction over Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst as shown in Fig. 88. The dissociation of NH3 into NH2 and the oxidation of NO to NO2 are the crucial steps in the NH3-SCR reaction on the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst. Throughout the NH3-SCR reaction cycle, the desired product (N2) is formed in both the reduction of Cu2+ and the oxidation of Cu+. Zhong et al. [249] investigated the SCR reaction mechanism of NO with NH3 on ZCuOH species by DFT calculations as shown in Fig. 89. During the half cycle of reduction, NH3 adsorbed on the ZCuOH active sites, then, the N-H bond of NH3 was cleaved and reacted with OH groups to form -NH2 and H2O molecules on the surface. Subsequently, -NH2 reacts with NO to form NH2NO, NH2NO decomposes into N2 and H2O, and the active site changes from ZCuOH to Cu+. In the half cycle of oxidation, NH3 and NO2 adsorb to the Cu site to form -NH2 and HONO. Then, NH2NO species is generated, which plays an important role in the reduction and half oxidation cycle. Finally, N2 and H2O were generated and desorbed from the surface. Cu dimer was also mentioned earlier as the active site of the reaction. Wang et al. [154] revealed the role of Cu dimer in the E-R mechanism, and the results are shown in Fig. 90. NO is first adsorbed at the surface oxygen vacancies to form [Cu-(NO)2-Cu]2+, and then [Cu-(NO)2-Cu]2+ is further activated to form a Cu dimer while releasing N2O. N2O is also adsorbed to form [Cu-N2O-Cu]2+ and is also activated to form a Cu dimer while releasing N2. The Cu dimer adsorbs gaseous NO to form nitrite [Cu-NO2-Cu]2+ and the unstable [Cu-NO2-Cu]2+ decomposes to form oxygen vacancies and release NO2. If NO2 is adsorbed, nitrate [Cu−NO3−Cu]2+ is generated, which is subsequently decomposed to release NO and O2. Xue et al. [250] found that liganded NH3, NH4 + and -NH2 on the Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst are important intermediates in the NH3-SCR reaction. Ammonia species adsorbed at the Lewis acid sites played a key role throughout the temperature range, while those adsorbed at the Brønsted acid site and -NH2 acted in the medium/low temperature region. The reaction pathway on Cu-ZSM-5 follows both E-R and L-H mechanisms at 150 °C and 300 °C. For Fe-based molecular sieve catalysts, Wang et al. [165] investigated the NH3-SCR reaction pathway on Fe-ZSM-5 and the results are shown in Fig. 91. They suggested that one possible reaction pathway is [Fe]+NH3+NO2 → 5[Fe-NO2-NH3] → 5[Fe-NO2]-1 → 5[Fe-NO2]-2 → 5[Fe-NO2]-3 → 5[FeOHNH2NO] → 5[FeOH]+NH2NO → 5[FeOH]+NH2O+N2. Firstly, NO2 and NH3 are adsorbed on the iron atoms to form the 5[Fe-NO2] species. Subsequently, one of the N=O bonds of NO2 is broken and the Fe atom is attracted to the O atom, which is also the rate-limiting step. After that, the Fe-O bond is broken and 5[Fe-NO2]-3 is formed. Then, gaseous NH3 is adsorbed onto 5[Fe-NO2]-3 to produce 5[FeOH-NH2NO]. Finally, NH2NO decomposes into N2 and H2O. There is another reaction route: [Fe]+NH3+NO2 → 5[Fe-NO2]-1+NH3 → 5[Fe-NO2]-2+NH3 → 5[FeO-NO]+NH3 → 5[Fe-NO-NH3] → 5[FeOH-NH2NO] → 5[FeOH]+NH2NO → 5[FeOH]+H2O+N2. From this, we can easily find that in this process, NH3 is not adsorbed on [Fe-NO2], but on a new intermediate product 5[FeO-NO], and that this intermediate product is converted from 5[Fe-NO2]-2. and the formation of 5[FeO-NO] is the rate-limiting step of this pathway. Shi et al. [251] proposed that in a standard SCR reaction, NO is oxidized to form ferric nitrate and nitrite, and it is difficult to re-oxidize Fe(II) to Fe(III), thus making the standard SCR less active. When NO2 is present in the reaction, it promotes the formation of surface nitrate and nitrite, while NH3 prevents further reaction of iron nitrate to form nitrite (Fig. 76 ). 6 Summary and outlook Molecular sieve catalysts are extensively investigated and have excellent performance, making them an excellent choice for NH3-SCR catalysts. In this paper, a systematic overview of the preparation, physicochemical properties, mechanisms of hydrothermal aging and poisoning of molecular sieve catalysts, and the mechanism of NH3-SCR reaction is presented. It is summarized as follows: 1. In molecular sieve catalysts, active metal ions provide redox sites, and molecular sieves have abundant acidic sites, as well as high specific surface area and stable crystal structure can make the active related active species fully dispersed in the catalyst. Molecular sieve catalysts can be mainly categorized into Cu-based, Fe-based molecular sieves, and of course, Mn-based and other molecular sieves. But the catalytic activity of the latter is far less than the former, but can be used as a doping element to improve the former molecular sieve, that is, composite metal molecular sieve catalysts. Cu-based molecular sieve tends to have better performance, but the hydrothermal stability, poisoning resistance is poor. The representative Cu-based molecular sieves are Cu-SSZ-13 and Cu-SAPO-34, which are CHA type molecular sieves. The Cu-AEI molecular sieves are also considered as Cu-CHA equivalents with good activity and stability. Fe-based molecular sieves have better high temperature catalytic activity. In order to pursue high activity and stability of molecular sieve catalysts, doping treatment is often required to form composite metal molecular sieve catalysts. The active elements will interact with each other after doping treatment to improve the catalytic activity or poisoning resistance. There are also many elements that can be doped, the more typical doping elements are selected and discussed in this paper. 2. Molecular sieves are generally prepared by hydrothermal synthesis of templating agents or by methods such as crystal transformation. Generally templating agents are expensive, although scholars have found cheap templating agents, the templating agents all need to be removed after calcination, which may cause damage to the structure of the molecular sieves and thus affect the catalytic activity. How to get rid of the dependence of templating agents to directly synthesize the corresponding zeolites is the direction of our efforts. In addition, the silica-aluminum ratio and the content of active elements in molecular sieve catalysts can be adjusted, which will affect the activity and stability of the catalysts. The temperature control in the synthesis, as well as the method of loading the active elements (impregnation, ion exchange, one-pot synthesis, etc.) has a great influence on the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, such as the size, shape, and state of the active substances. The superior synthesis method is the one-pot synthesis method, which synthesizes catalysts with better dispersion of active elements. Some post-synthesis treatments also have an effect, such as alkali leaching, loading of alkali metal co-cations, H2 reduction treatment, etc., which help to improve the stability and catalytic activity of the catalyst. In addition, graded zeolite catalysts have superior activity and stability compared to ordinary catalysts. During the synthesis process, shell structure (e.g. CeO2) can be added, which can improve the resistance to poisoning and hydrothermal aging. These are all the things that need to be considered in the synthesis of molecular sieve catalysts, which can guide future researchers to better synthesize molecular sieve catalysts. 3. The hydrothermal stability of the catalyst is critical. Hydrothermal aging is often the main cause of deactivation of NH3-SCR catalysts. In the case of molecular sieve catalysts, hydrothermal aging will cause the molecular sieve skeleton to de-aluminate and collapse as well as will cause the active metal ions to be transformed into metal oxides, which will result in pore clogging and ultimately lead to catalyst deactivation. Moreover, after hydrothermal aging, the anti-poisoning performance of the molecular sieve catalyst decreases due to the destruction of its structure. For low-temperature hydrothermal aging and high-temperature hydrothermal aging, there are different mechanisms, low-temperature hydrothermal aging generally does not destroy the structure of molecular sieves, but the active species and acid sites will be reduced, while high-temperature hydrothermal aging will cause the collapse of molecular sieve skeleton. Among the above molecular sieves, Cu-SAPO-34 is more special, which has excellent high-temperature hydrothermal stability but is deactivated at low temperatures. 4. Poisoning by inorganic elements deactivates the catalysts. S-poisoned molecular sieve catalysts are deactivated by the absence of active sites to generate sulfate or sulfite species, which clog the pores, or even destroy the skeleton to generate sulfoalumina compounds. Among these sulfur species, ammonium sulfate is easy to decompose, so the activity of S-poisoned molecular sieve catalysts can be partially regenerated after heating. P-poisoned catalysts generate P2O5 and PO3 −/PO4 3−, which occupy the active sites and block the pores, leading to the deactivation of the catalysts. In contrast, the loading of PO3 − in Cu-SAPO-34 improves the catalytic performance, which may be related to its self-generated composition (which can be synthesized by phosphoric acid). Alkali and alkaline-earth metals exchange active and acid sites or even cause backbone destruction, thus leading to deactivation, which is generally higher for metals with small diameters and high exchange capacity. 5. The mechanism of NH3-SCR reaction over molecular sieve catalysts can be categorized into E-R mechanism and L-H mechanism. The former is the reaction with other reactants after adsorption of NH3 or NO on acidic sites and activation, and the latter is the reaction after coadsorption and activation of NH3 and NO. Fe-based molecular sieve catalysts and Cu-based molecular sieve catalysts have different reaction paths due to the difference of active sites. Moreover, different temperatures and different molecular sieve carriers also affect the specific reaction paths. In addition, the acidic and redox sites on the catalysts play a decisive role in determining the high-temperature NH3-SCR activity and low-temperature NH3-SCR activity of the catalysts, respectively. It is hoped that this review will provide scholars with a better understanding of molecular sieve catalysts and provide ideas for the future development of molecular sieve catalysts. coredata.dc:description: NH3-SCR technology is a highly efficient denitrification technology that is widely used in the purification of diesel exhaust and coal-fired flue gas from thermal power plants. Molecular sieve catalysts have been extensively investigated for their high activity and selectivity. In this review, the preparation, structure, active sites and some resistances of Cu-based molecular sieve catalysts, Fe-based molecular sieve catalysts and composite metal molecular sieve catalysts are systematically investigated for relevant elaboration. In addition, the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over the catalysts is also explained. With the increasingly stringent requirements of NO x emission, we need to develop more efficient catalysts. This paper provides a summary of the hydrothermal aging stability and the inorganic element (S / P / Alkali and alkaline earth metal) poisoning mechanisms as well as the influence of the preparation process in the molecular sieve catalysts, and we hope this review contributes to the development of molecular sieve catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Research status and outlook of molecular sieve NH3-SCR catalysts
